description:
On my visit to San Francisco, I was craving ramen more than anything else and I was delighted to find this spot.

The broth of the Curry Ramen is outstanding, I also liked the sushi options they have.
author: Gina G.

description:
Ramen is a Japanese adaptation of Chinese wheat noodles. Ramen was first introduced to Japan in 1859 by Chinese immigrants. Many amazing ramen restaurants' owners in Japan have Chinese descendants. So I am always hopeful when trying Chinese owned ramen shop here or in Europe. Sadly I have never encountered a good one outside of Japan.

I sensed star of anise in Coco's broth. It does not belong there. I think when you add anise in the broth, it become Chinese noodle not ramen.
author: Chie J.

description:
Now let me start with saying that I have gone to 4 different Ramen places (1 in SoCal, 3 here in SF) and I just could not get myself to like any of them. I gave up on Ramen until I came here!

I ordered the Miso Ramen and substituted the pork belly for chicken katsu and boy did it make a difference, for me at least. The broth was perfect, the chicken was just the right amount as was everything else. I definitely enjoyed this spot!
author: Karina R.

description: Light dinner. Excellent flavor soup base. Pork belly with just right amount of fat. Noodles were AL dente.  Ate Saturday night and no wait for table. Fast eat and run place.
author: Clifford W.

description:
This is one ramen spot I have been waiting awhile to try, So after a cold cold cold day during a Giants game, we decided to warm up by having some ramen. 

Yelp said there was no waitist, but we ended up having to sign the waitlist, but we were seated right away but it was at the window seat. For awhile, I thought they forgot about us because the people waiting for a seat were standing RIGHT behind us. 

But good thing, they gave us our tea and water. That seat would have been great on a warmer night, but I felt the AC was just right on top of us. Their ramen is a bit on the pricey side.. Would I come back? Probably not. 

Parking is very scarce and it is all street parking. But we were lucky to get a spot nearby. 

I think they were annoyed at us because we kept asking for refills on our tea, they gave us a little teapot, but we drank it all and had to ask for more tea. They came back and gave us TWO little teapots of tea so they could stop coming to refill. 

The atmosphere was kinda dim and dark...they had a few choices of broth which was good and they explained it on the menu.... but....

Would I come back? Probably not....
author: Eugenia W.

description:
I have lived down the block from this place since it opened and I finally decided to give it a try! I had heard only good things, and I was not disappointed. I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen ($12.95), while my lovely girlfriend ordered the miso ramen ($12.95). As an appetizer we got the Takoyaki ($6.00). I have always wanted to try it so I thought I'd give it a shot! 

The Tonkatsu ramen was good! I had no complaints about my meal overall. It came with 3 good sized pieces of Pork belly, which is just about right, the noodles were tasty, and the broth was really good. My girlfriend especially enjoyed her Miso ramen, and I had some as well and thought it was good as well, even though miso isn't my favorite. 

The Takoyaki tasted very good. It was my first time having it so I don't have anything to compare it to, but it tasted good to me! 

The venue is a bit small, and once more people started to come it did get a bit cramped, but I go to restaurants to eat. As long as the food is good, and I'm not feeling uncomfortable I'm not going to lower my rating because of how cramped it was. Everything was good. Wasn't the best ramen I ever had, but I think 4/5 stars is a perfect review for it. Definitely a must try!
author: John James M.

description:
My brother and I came at 6:30pm on a Saturday and found ourselves with a short 5 minute wait. We did end up sharing a table with another party of 2 though because space is a premium here.

I opted for garlic miso ramen, mild spicy, with pork shoulder while my brother went with curry ramen, medium spicy, with pork belly. At first, I felt like my noodles were a little less than al dente and too chewy, but as I let it soak in the broth a little longer, it did eventually reach the right chewiness for me. But what was most memorable for me was the pork shoulder! Most places slice their char-siu paper thin so to come to a place that gave (3) solid 1/4" slices was amazing! It was also tender and super flavorful to boot - a must try, in my opinion! I also traded one slice to my brother for a slice of the pork belly. It was also very good: tender and melt in your mouth decadent...but I definitely felt like the char-siu is a winner here. We also opted to share an order of agedashi tofu. Delivered piping hot and freshly fried, I thought it hit all the right notes.

All in all, as far as ramen goes in San Francisco, I have to say that Coco's Ramen was probably one of the better ones I've had lately. Portion size is very fair, quality is great, and price point is right without all the nickel and dime extras.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Y'all, this is NOT GOOD RAMEN. I was suckered into coming here because I didn't want to go into Japantown and wait hella long for ramen, so I decided to check out this place because it had a decent Yelp rating, and...

I honestly have no idea how this place has a 4-star review because it tastes like... regular 'ol Chinese noodle soup. I got the Tonkotsu Ramen and it tasted like anything but. The fattiness and richness of the soup just wasn't up to snuff, and everything else about the experience, including the chashu and noodles was kinda gross.

On top of that, I also tried the Chicken Karaage which was a major disappointment as well. It's dry, but not even really that crispy and tbh I'd prefer to order some popcorn chicken from a local boba shop or something rather than get the chicken karaage here again.

If you're tempted to come here because you think you'll get okay ramen, THINK AGAIN. I honestly want to say I have pretty low standards when it comes to being satisfied by food - most of my low reviews come from places having bad service, but this place just isn't really good ramen. If you're looking for ramen, I highly suggest you try somewhere else.
author: Brian W.

description: Let me start by saying i am an avid ramen eater it's my favorite food. This ramen is probably my top favorite. Noodles were super thick and perfect softness. Broth was delicious and spicy. Place is small and simple with huge flavor. Can't wait to go back for this ramen again!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place has a very hipster feel, so it's pretty cool.   We took lyft here because we were afraid parking was gonna be hard.    We came around a Monday night and the place was surprisingly packed!   They gave us one of the last tables, which we got super lucky.   The menu had a variety of appetizers and skewers.   And the other menu had their ramen choices.  

We got the calamari and it was pretty good.  The batter was perfect and it was fresh.  The Chicken Karaage was ok, the batter was a little be too much.   We also got the beef tongue skewers, which was overly seasoned.    It was so salty and chewy.  I felt they overcooked it. 

For the Ramen they have flavors such as Miso, tonkatsu, seafood, curry and much more.  My friend loved their Curry one so much and you can tell them what level of spiciness you want.  I got the tonkatsu flavor one and i loved the soup.   You have options of getting your ramen with pork shoulder or the pork belly.   The pork belly usually has more fat, so if you like that, i recommend it.  However, i like the pork shoulder because it was very tender.  

The service was pretty good, the noise level is a little loud, it was hard hearing my friends.   I would come back for the ramen, but might avoid the appetizers.
author: Belinda C.

description:
This is my favorite ramen place in Mission/Bernal. 

First off, yes, the restaurant is tiny, you might have to share a table, and there will be a wait. But the food more than makes up for it. There's a reason there's always a line. 

I've had the Tonkatsu, Shoyu, Shio, and Veggie ramens, and they're all quite good. The noodle is fresh and al dente, the broth is nice and flavorful (if a little spicy). I love the soft boiled egg that always comes with it, and the chaushu is wonderful (but the pork belly can get just a little dry). As for apps, the Kabocha is AMAZING. 

Service is normally very fast, they're courteous, but also not over the top. Overall, this is def a regular spot for me.
author: Sophie W.

description:
I came here on a Thursday afternoon for lunch and it was very quiet. The restaurant seemed authentic but the pop music playing in the background didn't fit the vibe. I'm sure it gets much busier and trendier in the evening. I got the miso ramen and was not disappointed. I substituted chicken katsu (super yum) for pork for an extra charge of a few dollars. The menu was a little confusing because it seemed like pork was the only protein option for each dish. 

For vegetarians: My friend who is a vegetarian ordered hers with tofu but found pork in it which was a little unsettling.
author: Annabel W.

description: Came in for dinner to Coco's. Pretty busy and was sat at the bar. What can I say? Service was very attentive, food was delicious, and environment was nice! I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen with black garlic with a side of pork belly yakitori. I added the pork belly yakitori to the ramen but I think I should have just ordered the stewed pork belly that was made for it. That is my only tip. Definitely want to try the other broths like the curry or soy combos!
author: Gil M.

description:
I stopped by Coco's Ramen with a couple of friends on a Sunday evening, and the restaurant was pretty full. The wait wasn't too bad, and we were able to be seated in ten or so minutes. The interior was very cozy, with dimmed lighting and is good for having conversations without too much noise.

The ramen menu is pretty straightforward with your popular ramen types such as shoyu (soy sauce base), miso (creamy base), shio (salt base), and even other options such as vegetarian or curry broth. For each ramen, you can adjust the spice level as well as choices of garlic and type of pork in your soup (pork belly or chashu). I liked how they used both pork + chicken stock in the broth here as some places that use pure pork tend to have soups that are a bit too heavy for my liking. 

I went with the miso ramen and added garlic in the broth for a more refreshing taste. The miso ramen came with bean sprouts, bamboo, and seaweed along with the pork belly. I'm not even a huge fan of pork, but their pork belly was extremely tasty and felt like it melted in my mouth. I'm always a huge fan of spicy food, so I got my broth extra spicy. If you're accustomed to spice, spicy or extra spicy is fine and not over-the-top. Japanese style ramen tends to be on the more hearty side rather than spicy, so don't worry too much about going up on the spice levels here. The portion sizes were very fair for the price, as there are definitely other ramen joints in SF that give you less for a higher price. I regretted not getting the side of extra noodles to really use the leftover broth after my first round. 

Good portions, cozy setting, and delicious pork belly: what're you waiting for? Definitely recommend checking Coco's ramen out if you're in SF.
author: Mike C.

description:
My friends and I were just walking around and we were craving for ramen so stopped by here. We got in right before they opened at 5:30pm so we didn't have to wait in a long line. Lucky for us.

I didn't have high expectations and didn't really know what to expect but it was a nice pleasant surprise. I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen, my friend ordered the shio ramen, and another ordered the curry ramen. We all liked our food very much.

My spicy tonkatsu was with the charsiu because I wanted more meat than fat. The size was decent. Not too little, not too big. My soup was quite flavorful. It wasn't spicy enough though so maybe next time I'll get very spicy. The meat was tender and the noodle was good. 

I'd definitely come back to this place to try other ramen options.
author: Ngoc P.

description: This is one of my favorite little spots in San Francisco. Limited menu with dishes they just do really well. Perfectly fried karrage with a hint of lemon and yummy and light gyoza. All the ramen and Thai food are consistent and have great spice. A great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Laurel M.

description: this place is bomb the extra spicy tonkatsu is rich and deep yes yes in my mouf!
author: Rob C.

description:
I wasn't satisfied with anything that I ate here, unfortunately... I'm a pretty avid eater of ramen and maybe it was just an off kind of night. 

Why I was here // Came here on a Friday night around 5:30pm. I'm a bit under the weather and I told my bf I wanted something to warm my soul...his answer was ramen. 

Parking // Street parking, after 6pm you don't have to pay for meter, but before then, make sure to have a few quarters in your pocket. 

Service // I felt mixed about their service. When we first arrived it was pretty empty, maybe a like 3 other parties in the restaurant with ample seating. They asked us to sit at the bar, but we wanted a table, because their bar area is directly in front of the register where the other waitresses hang out...we wanted a bit more privacy while eating our food. They give us the table, but remark that normally they are so busy and that we would have to share a table...ok, that's fine with me...I just didn't want to sit at the bar with uncomfortable chairs. 
Their bench seating is extremely uncomfortable, the table almost touches the tops of my thighs...

Food // Disappointed 
-Appetizer // Beef tongue yakitori // 5.00 // This really whet our appetite! This was delicious and had really good seasoning. 
-Appetizer // Fried kabocha // 10.00 // Looks unique but is NOT worth it. Terribly bland. The waitress even mentioned that they didn't season with sugar to keep the kabocha flavor...but it was bland and had a strange sour flavor to it. They put an egg inside though... cool?
-Main // spicy miso ramen with chashu // The broth was salty and thin; miso broth was advertised as creamy but it was completely clear and weak as a broth base. The spice level however was pretty good. The egg was nicely cooked but the chashu was dry and was a bit hard to swallow. 

Overall // Won't be coming back. There are better places around to check out.
author: Emily T.

description:
I came here after 2 other ramen places i went to was closed, so was in a grouchy mood

But the food here cheered me right up!  I had their extra spicy black garlic ponkatsu ramen and it was one of the best i had in awhile.  Paired it with thier house sake which was very sweet and smooth.  Service was very quick, but the one downside was my particular waiter didnt seem to speak english.  I had to point at the menu to get them to understand what i wanted
author: John K.

description: A really cool little spot to have a casual dinner. Great ramen, very large portions. They also have add ons that you can get for not much more such as more pork belly or fried chicken. The staff moves fast when it's busy but they are really friendly.
author: Doriana B.

description:
Yet another ramen joint in San Francisco.  Good enough to satisfy a hankering, but not something to go out of your way for nor subject yourself to a long wait.  Oddly enough, it's hard to find a tonkotsu broth better than what's offered by that chain, Ippudo.

Fried Kabocha: This looked too cool not to get.  Kinda like a Scotch Egg, but with sweet kabocha instead of sausage.  Unfortunately, it looked a lot better than it tasted.  While the thin outer shell was nice and crispy, the inside was cold and pasty.  Like this had been sitting in the fridge and they threw it in a deep fryer for a few seconds.  Also, it seemed like an excessive amount of kabocha paste compared to the amount of egg.  That really reinforced the pastiness.

Tonkotsu Ramen w/ Pork Belly & Black Garlic: It was decent, but nothing to go out of your way for.  The broth looked white and cloudy, but it didn't seem that rich.  Noodles were ok, chewy as they should be.  There was a generous amount of pork belly.  Taste like it was braised a very long time in 5-spice; a lot of luxurious fat layers seemed to have melted away.
author: Adam B.

description:
I had a subpar dinner here, reasons being:
- We were seated at a table for four, sharing it with a random couple. It was too close for comfort. There was a table open but we were told it was reserved for parties of three or more. Minutes later, they seated a couple at that table. Another table opened up and when asked if we could sit there, they denied us again.
- I ordered the veggie ramen and was given an egg that I did not order. This would be a delight for anyone else but unfortunately I do not eat egg.
- Our server informed us the medium spiciness was barely spicy. I ordered mild to be on the safe side. It was too spicy for me.
- No vegan option for ramen, only vegan broth with egg noodles. You pick three add-ons which barely top your noodles.
- Bad service - no water refills.
- Overall, the ramen wasn't even good. Definitely not enough the redeem the poor service we endured.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I came back here for the second time and I didn't enjoy the ramen as much as I did during the first visit. I think the noodles were too thick for my liking and the pork belly were too sweet - it reminds me of the pork belly that gets marinated in sweet broth in Taiwanese or Cambodian cooking. I didn't think it worked well with the ramen broth - I would enjoy the pork belly alone with rice so that it can balanced out the sweetness.

However, definitely add BLACK GARLIC to your Spicy Miso because it does add more flavors to the broth.
author: Chariya S.

description:
Tldr - I literally want to inject the Broth from that ramen straight in to my blood stream.

Oh dear lord. I stumbled to this place on a whim after going to best buy and learning that they were sold out of apple TVs. On a side note - the hdmi adapter cable for surfacebook laptops is SO DAMN EXPENSIVE like wat 75 dollars for an adapter not including a cable? I was like screw that Amazon it is man.

Anyway back to the point. A very disappointed samraaj came here after an unfortunate misadventure in best buy and it is legit the best ramen I have had. We got the tonkotsu ramen as per suggestion from the SUPER DOPE hostess. This did not disappoint even slightly. Actually it did the opposite; it appointed.

The broth is rich and creamy with umami flavor to die for. The soft boiled egg was perfectly cooked and the bamboo shoots offered a tender flavor that complimented the broth perfectly. My friend legit said it is better than almost every ramen place he went to in Japan.

Also the gyoza I can rave about for like a year but this is already too long I feel lol. Just get it lol

My photos suck bc I forgot to take em till after the meal
author: Samraaj B.

description:
This place is amazing! Definitely my new favorite place to get ramen in SF. 

I got the tonkatsu ramen with pork belly, extra spicy and really enjoyed it! Sometimes with tonkatsu broth the soup is way too fatty/oily and makes the meal really heavy and hard to enjoy, but the broth here was just the right amount of rich. It was super flavorful and addicting. The 3 slices of pork belly were so tender they were almost falling apart and honestly SO GOOD. 

For appetizers our table got agedashi tofu, chicken kaarage, and a whole grilled squid. The tofu and chicken were okay, but the squid was amazing! I feel like squid is easy to overcook but this was cooked just right and still very tender. 

Highly recommend!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Here for the 5th time still love it.

Came here with a small group

Ordered 6 kinda of ramen they were all good, soup, ramen, meat, flavor were all perfect for us. 

Sushi was just ok, understood they are not specialize in sushi.
author: Mack A.

description:
This place consistently has great noodles. The broth is always good. Service is fine, no complaints.

Where this place falls off is their consistency. Photo of the gross egg I was served below. It was over cooked. Chashu isn't consistent taste-wise, sometimes it's way too salty, sometimes it's fine, as of lately it's too salty and too chewy, and today it was served to me cold, salty, and chewy...  Broth isn't consistently amazing and I've tried the shoyu, tonkatsu, miso, curry, and seafood ramens.

A little bit more in depth rating...

Noodles - 4.5/5
Broth - 4/5
Chashu - 2.75/5
Soft Boiled Egg - 1/5

I was debating on rating them a 4 or 5 before today's visit, but after today's cold & chewy chashu and over cooked egg I was debating between 3 or 4. At the end of the day this place is a 4 because the noodles are great and the broth is good with consistency breaking them away from 5/5. However, if today was my first visit I'd give them a 3/5 because the cold, chewy chashu and over cooked egg was insulting. I kid you not on how tough it was for me to bite out a piece of the chashu, I almost gave up midway on biting it because I couldn't enjoy my meal any longer. If Yelp gave 1-10 ratings this place is a solid 7/10.

Will I come back here after today's poor experience? Well, I'm a local. I can see myself coming back maybe once every year or two, but if the next time I come and I'm served subpar chashu & over cooked eggs then I'm out.

Update: Changed from 4 to 3 stars because I believe the score should reflect a business' current ability. My last few trips were mediocre and not deserving of 4 stars.

Noodles - 4.5/5
Broth - 3.75/5
Chashu - 2/5
Soft boiled egg - 1/5
Consistency - 2/5
Service - 4/5
author: Alvin D.

description: Okay for anyone who gave Coco Ramen anything less than a 5 star, y'all are crazy! My friend and I have tried different ramen places in the city and we always come back to Coco because it is seriously unreal on how amazing their Ramen is. We are here pretty much every single week. The service is quick and the food is even better. I get the shoyu ramen, mouth watering! Thank you for your yummy food and never failing me.
author: Aymee L.

description:
Love this place! Stopped by around 7:00 pm on Sunday with my friend. Service was great, the lady was super nice. We tried Kobocha and it was made with mashed pumpkin with cooked egg in the middle, and with spicy mayo sauce. It tasted so good and I think Kobocha is their best! You should definitely try it out.

I got the miso ramen with chashu. The broth is rich and flavorful. The soft boiled egg and chashu are perfectly cooked. Everything is great. Worth a visit!
author: Lin L.

description: Popular restaurant! People were arriving 20 minutes before open, even myself. Great ramen, and the pumpkin appetizer is delicious!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I honestly don't know why this place only has a 3.5 average rating. I probably ate half my meal making weird happy noises with my eyes closed in ecstasy. With such flavorful ramen, friendly servers, easy street parking, decent neighborhood, and the lack of a line out the door, it's my go-to ramen spot in the city. 

Coco's has 2 sections -- if you're facing the establishment from the street, the left side is the "ramen" side and the right side is "everything else." However, you can get ramen on the right side as well. Don't worry, it confuses me too. 

My favorite is the tonkotsu ramen with pork belly. The half soft boiled egg is PERFECTLY cooked -- warm with perfectly gooey consistency. The pork belly is definitely the star of the show: melt-in-your-mouth soft and not overly fatty. The noodles are cooked to al dente perfection. You can really taste the garlic, too; it makes for a rich and creamy experience! 

I'm a little sad that this review might help them get bumped up in their Yelp rating, which means that the place will get more crowded. But these guys deserve it! I'll be back again soon!!
author: Christine L.

description:
Simple. 
Sometimes I just want ramen. I don't want some fancy interpretation of ramen- and I also don't want some Asian person being rude to me. This was great.
Great service and great ramen. 
It was $20 for ramen after tip bc the kimchi was $3 :/
But other than that it was great.
author: Julianna I.

description: Tonkatsu is off the hook! It has its own Smokey distinct garlicky flavor that explodes your taste buds into happiness!!!!!!
author: Robert G.

description:
I came in early on a Saturday night with a party of 14 props. They accommodated us pretty quickly. The restaurant is actually pretty big, I can't imagine waits being that long. 

I got the Tonkatsu ramen with garlic, medium spicy and charsu. It was very good, tasty. The noodles were spot on with my expectations. I recommend you try it out.
author: Bryan N.

description: Oh Coco's, how I love your ramen. Tonkatsu pork belly mild spicy. It's just so good. I've tried other soup bases but that's my personal favorite. Mild is still spicy...they don't kid around. Black garlic is a good addition too or corn if I'm feeling adventurous. I could eat it every week and almost do. Just don't forget they're closed on Tuesdays. Only reason I'm knocking a star is because I don't like the seating arrangement. I don't always feel comfortable sharing a table with strangers when they keep looking at you while you're having a conversation with someone across the table. The tables are very wide so it's not very private. I much prefer getting the window seat or sitting at the bar.
author: Laura D.

description: What a great ramen house in Bernal/Mission. We stumbled across this place by accident and so thankful we decided to stop in! Cozy, neighborhood feel, friendly staff and comfortable tables. We started with the best chicken wings I've ever had (highly recommend), followed by generous bowls of ramen with tasty, hot broth and equally delicious toppings. Good value, quality ingredients, superb foodie experience.
author: Rich S.

description:
3.5/5
Came with a friend who recommended this spot as a solid can't-go-wrong type of joint. Parking in the area was a bit difficult and we had to circle a few times before finding a metered spot nearby. There's a good amount of seating but since it was a Friday night around 7pm we ended up getting seats at the bar.

The TLDR version is: appetizers were decent, ramen itself was meh to average.

Appetizers:
1) Pork Gyoza: Much larger than a lot of gyoza I've had. Very thin exterior and a flavorful filling. I think it could have been fried a bit longer but that's just personal preference. It was still a bit pricy for what you get though (4/5)
2) Squid Leg Karaage: My friend's appetizer. Legs weren't too chewy and batter was nicely seasoned. Not something I'd normally order but I enjoyed it (3.5/5)
3) Bacon wrapped mochi: I keep ordering these but I never enjoy them very much. Bacon wasn't crispy enough to contrast the soft mochi and mochi wasn't sweet enough to compliment the bacon's saltiness. Not bad but kind of just tasted neutral. (3/5)
4) Beef tongue skewer: Very well seasoned and not too dry considering how thin the slices were. (4/5)

Ramen:
I got the black garlic tonkotsu w/ chashu and my friend got the spicy black garlic tonkotsu w/ chashu. Despite the fact we almost had the same dish her's was far saltier than mine. The broth wasn't very rich and the black garlic oil didn't really add much. The chashu flavor good, slightly sweet and tender but some bits were a bit too dry for me. The noodles were on the thicker side which would work well if the broth was richer. Overall not bad but since this was the main course I was a bit disappointed. (3/5)

Overall Coco's isn't an awful ramen place but there's better out there.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Unfortunately, only average for me despite the generally glowing reviews from my Yelp friends.

I tried both the tonkatsu and the curry ramen.
The tonkatsu broth was watered down, not the rich experience (in both flavor and texture) that defines tonkatsu. Curry broth was the same.

Noodles itself were decent, good bouncy texture. Sad that the broth didn't cling to the noodles.

Service is attentive but not the friendliest.

Good option if you live in the area, but not a destination spot. I will be fulfilling my ramen needs elsewhere.
author: Emily C.

description: Their ramen is not authentic japanese flavor. I ordered tonkotsu ramen. A little too salty. While the chashu and egg are cooked well, the broth doesn't have the texture and flavor that make a ramen broth. I did notice that this restaurant is owned by non-japanese. My bad... I usually try to avoid chinese-owned ramen restaurant. It just doesn't work for me.
author: Shinta L.

description:
Originally my family and I had wanted to visit the ramen place a few stores down from Coco's. But we were surprised to see that Coco's had customers coming in and out on a Tuesday! Seeing the fuller restaurant, we decided to give Coco's a try since the reviews seemed pretty favorable regarding the ramen. The ramen shop is not too small - there are a good number of tables, but they only had half of their restaurant open for lunch service. The other half (seemingly a sushi bar) was closed otherwise there would have been many more tables. 

Their menu is quite simple. They have a section for appetizers, yakitori, fried appetizers, and vegetables, but what they are popular for is their ramen. The prices are a bit more expensive than what you would pay for ramen in SGV, but it is SF - they offer the regular seafood, tonkotsu, miso, shoyu, vegetable, curry, and shio. Some broths are marked light, creamy, classic, flavorful, etc. which was interesting to see. What I found to be interesting was that instead of the usual chashu, they also give the option of adding braised pork belly to the ramen. 

My family all tried the various ramen - tonkotsu and shoyu, but I decided to go with the curry. It's definitely more interesting, and I read a ton of good things about it. A ton of people also recommend adding the black garlic (additional $1), but I think all the bowls tasted fine without the black garlic. I was able to try all three bowls - they tasted pretty good; tonkotsu was more flavorful while the shoyu was a bit on the lighter side. 

I ended up being super glad that I went with the curry ramen. For $11.50, it was a pretty good deal! There was a good amount of ingredients inside, including half of a soft boiled egg. There was also bamboo shoots and green onion, but what stood out was the curry broth. I've tried curry ramen that didn't taste too great, but Coco's really perfected the broth! Not too heavy, more like a thick soup that went well with the ramen noodles. There was also carrots and potatoes in the broth, but the stand out ingredient was definitely the braised pork belly. If you love pork belly, you have got to order this instead of the chashu. It was sweet, tender, and melt in my mouth delicious. And they gave me a really decent portion, so I felt like I had a good ratio of pork belly to noodles! Noodles were cooked well - nothing too memorable about the ramen. I would come back to get this again. 

tl;dr - If you're craving ramen in the SF area, I would definitely recommend Coco's! Especially the pork belly with curry ramen! I overheard a customer next to me opting to forgo the chashu and pork belly and all I could think was ... give it to me! Glad I was able to find this place - worth the price.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
It's okay. Nothing memorable. Will return to give it a second try just to see if opinion changes.

Warning. I'm a ramen snob. I lived in Japan for a number of years and ramen was my go-to, so i've eaten my weights worth of it. I base most of all my ramen experiences on soup and the soft boiled egg. You've been warned! 

Came here on a weekend to grab a quick dinner. They open at 5:30 so we got here right when it opened, so it wasn't that busy. I really wanted to try this place based on the reviews, but found this place to only be so-so.

We ordered some calamari and the tonkotsu ramen. The calamari was good. It was fried well and the squid wasn't chewy when you ate it. I liked the spicy mayo it came with as well. My tonkotsu ramen was underwhelming. The broth was salty and not flavorful or rich. I was expecting a creamy, pork bone taste and all I got was salt. The egg was cooked perfectly and marinated so well. The noodles were also cooked very well. Just the right. Chewy and not soggy or undercooked. I opted for the chashu and it was a little dry and un-flavorful. I will try the pork belly next time.
author: Junella T.

description: Decent enough but nothing special.  Dark atmosphere catering to young peeps.  Had the grilled hamachi Kama.  Nicely charred and seasoned.  Sorta on the small side for $12.  Wifey had the shoyu ramen which was as okay.  Parking is horrendous as usual on Mission street.
author: Joel M.

description:
This place was just okay. My boyfriend has been here once before and had a great experience, so he wanted me to try it. There were 3 parties ahead of us. We waited about 10-15 minutes, not bad at all. 

I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with pork belly (non-spicy) and added corn. The presentation wasn't great to start with. I couldn't really tell what toppings were in my bowl from first glance. The broth was pretty bland and tasted watered down. I wasn't a fan of the pork belly either because of its sweetness, but I know that's just my personal preference. I was expecting something more savory. Toppings were good though. Egg, although overlooked, was good and my sweet corn was delicious! My boyfriend ordered the miso ramen with pork belly, medium spicy, and added bamboo shoots and extra egg. His broth tasted different than the first time he came here, even though he ordered the same thing. It was watered down and lacked flavor. The pork belly came really fatty and not crispy like the first time he says.

The service was alright. We were next on the list to be seated and a large table opened up (big enough to very tightly seat 6). The waiter asked the party who was after us if they wanted to share a table with us.. I think he should've asked us first considering we were next. So we were seated next to another pair and it just wasn't enough space for 2 pairs of strangers to comfortably enjoy dinner. 

Overall, I don't think I will be back. It was worth a try though. I know this place has pretty good reviews, so maybe we came on an off day. My boyfriend did mention that the last time he was here, it was during the first hour of their dinner service. This time, we were here closer towards the end. We think that has something to do with the lower quality food.
author: Ariana T.

description:
Delicious place!

Very intimate and dim lighting! 
Less than 10 min from my house also which is a plus!

Eats: 

Tonkatsu ramen, w/ pork shoulder (very rich and flavorful)
Black garlic ($1 extra - didn't notice a distinct flavor but maybe if I tried the ramen w/o it I might notice a difference) 

Came with all the fixings (half an egg, bamboo shoots, seaweed..)


Service was fast (sat at the bar) 

Small area, so everyone is a little squished together but I like the coziness of it! They also have sushi that looked amazing! Hard to find good sushi AND ramen places all in one. 

Would def be back!
author: Janessa H.

description: Came in around 5:30pm, the worker greeted me and asked if I wanted to sit on the high chair near the window or the stools at the bar. I chose to sit at the bar because the sun kept blinding my damn eyes lol. So I love miso ramen so of course that is what I had ordered. Yes, the broth was very creamy and flavorful. The chashu was soooo yummy, I'm glad they given more than one piece of meat unlike other restaurants and the broth was incredibly flavorful. Well done Coco Ramen, 5 stars!
author: Kristi A.

description:
A and I came here last night for dinner since we wanted something quick and relatively healthy after cooking became impractical. We decided to try Coco's based on Yelp rating and location. We were prepared to have a wait based on other reviews but were able to be sat at the bar right away. Apparently they also own the next door restaurant which serves Sushi AND Ramen so if you're going with a pickier group, that may be a good option.

We ordered:

-Shio Ramen, Spicy with Pork Shoulder and Black Garlic ($11.50 + $1 for Black Garlic): This was mine and it was good. Tasty but a bit salty and not nearly enough veggies. The Pork Shoulder was a nice light addition instead of the Pork Belly you could opt for.

-Shoyu Ramen with Pork Belly ($11.50): This was A's and it was good too. Very light but the Pork belly was an interesting contrast. Less salty than mine but still skimpy on the veggies. A was hungry at the end of the meal.

Overall, Coco's was average. The service was quick (if not a bit brusque) and the price was right. I think if we come back we would probably try some of their appetizers since they looked really good and seemed to be popular. I honestly think Kama Sushi on Church has better Ramen for the same price and bigger servings.
author: Carrie W.

description:
My first experience here was tainted because I walked outside after dinner to find that my car, as well as all the cars parked behind me on the same block, were sideswiped by an idiot drunk driver. And I thought I was lucky to find nearby parking...

Almost 2 years later, I decided it was about time to give this place another shot. After all, it's a pretty convenient location to get to, especially considering that all the ramen places in between San Mateo and San Francisco suck major ****. Being right off the San Jose Ave exit, I was determined to make Coco's Ramen my stop for great quality ramen without having to go too much out of my way.

The decision: OMG, WHAT CAR ACCIDENT?!?! 

Jk, it wasn't that over the top amazing to make me forget what happened, but I definitely had one excellent bowl of ramen.

As I usually get at ramen shops, I ordered the tonkotsu ramen, medium spicy. But at Coco's you get the additional option of adding BLACK GARLIC-- um, yes! The black garlic delivers a deep umami flavor that enhances the richness of the slowly simmered tonkotsu broth. Seriously freaking good. My only critique is, as other Yelpers have pointed out, that their levels of spicy are a bit watered down. For sure I'm going to order my bowl extra spicy next time.

Other menu items:
-COCO'S GYOZA (6pc not the 4pc menu option because that's different): I know they're just potstickers, but these were some of the best potstickers I've ever had. First off, I never order potstickers but I was starving and wanted something that wouldn't fill me up before the ramen came. To my pleasant surprise, the gyoza were handmade and the filling was really delicious. Moreover, it's served w/ chinkiang vinegar, aka the vinegar usually served with XLB. It's like they knew I have a weird affinity for vinegars...
-GRILLED WHOLE SQUID w/ spicy mayo sauce: Perfectly grilled but served plain w/ spicy mayo on the side. I also don't really think the spicy mayo was the right pairing for the squid, but sprinkle some shichimi on that baby and it's good to go (straight to your mouth).

I will definitely be back here more often for my ramen fix. IF I can find parking. It was taking way too long to find street parking so I parked in the Wells Fargo lot for a whopping $12. Womp, I just can't win with this neighborhood.
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: I randomly looked up Ramen in sf. And this magical place was given to me as an option. I ordered the spicy Tonkotsu ramen with pork belly... omg it was so good. The meat was tender and had an amazing taste, the noodles were cooked perfectly and the amount of spicy was heaven. Not to mention the egg was a perfectly cooked( not over cooked thou). And of course the broth was is amazingly good. Staff was very attentive and friendly. The place is clean and pretty quiet. But it was after 9:00 so maybe that was just because it was close to closing time. I'd recommend you come or order before 930 as I saw them turn away a few customers that came in. Will definitely be coming back thou.
author: Lucy R.

description: Food quality is really bad.....we ordered the beef tongue and it's served cold and not fresh! (Feels like they used the one left from yesterday) Skewers and fried items are all cold and tasteless. Oyster and ramen are just okay.... the only thing that's good is the soft boiled eggs. However, won't come for second time and highly don't recommend this place.
author: Anrui L.

description:
An OK place for ramen

Located near the Mission district, I had bookmarked this place for almost a year, and finally had a chance to try it out!

When we got it, it was no longer rush hour, so there were a lot of empty tables. We wanted to sit at an empty table, but for some reason the server insisted we sit at the bar stools at the windows :(

Still, the decor inside is pretty good. A lot of "wood" and ambience that makes the place feel like a japanese ramen room. You get a bottle of water using a sake bottle which is pretty neat. The taste of the ramen is also pretty nice, especially for a rainy day. I got the extra spicy ramen which was indeed red in color, and tasted pretty spicy (although still not spicy enough for my taste! But am sure it is a lot of spicy for most people). The portions are ok, with an ok amount of meat, and the noodles were pretty medium chewy.

Overall, a pretty good place to get some good ramen.
author: Henry L.

description: Thought it was good ramen not great.  Egg overcooked.  My hot sake wasn't too hot.  We went too early as well. It was like Romper Room with all the little kids!
author: Jeff C.

description:
We had a good experience here - tasty ramen, good service, pleasant ambiance, and reasonable prices.

I had the curry ramen, which was very flavorful, and really enjoyed it.  My husband had the shoyu ramen, which he said was good but not great.  We also got an order of the chicken lollipops, which were pretty good.  The cold house sake was very good (and well-priced, at $4 for a small carafe that served two)!

We sat at the bar, and experienced pleasant, friendly service.  We would have preferred that the food and drink arrival be staggered, instead of having all the items come out at the same time. The ramen came out very quickly and was followed rapidly by the chicken lollipops. 

The place was cozy, clean, and not too loud on a Saturday night, which was nice.  

Overall, a great spot for ramen in Bernal!
author: Barnali D.

description:
Coco's Ramen is a great neighborhood ramen spot. I live ~5 minutes away and have been here half a dozen times. I detest the culture of "waiting for 45 minutes for ramen" and never having to wait for a table at Coco's his a huge pro for me.

Food wise, the menu is pretty bare bones; they have the standard ramen flavors (tonkatsu, shio, shoyu etc...) as well as a seafood and vegetarian option. The noodles here are cooked on the more al dente side which is my preference. If you are a big meat eater, it may be worth asking for extra chashu or pork belly, but the 2 pieces they provide are plenty satisfying for me.

Apart from their ramen, they have this one very unique kobocha appetizer that is a soft boiled egg inside a crust of fried pumpkin. Its fairly heavy for 2 people but I would recommend getting it if in a group of 3+
author: Amy T.

description: If you get fresh ramen noodle at a Japanese grocery store, you can make this by yourself.  Broth was watery and not flavorful either.  Fish karaage was dry and smothered in sauce.
author: M G.

description:
Do not recommend the curry ramen. It is very liquidy and not curry. 
They charge $3 FOR chicken instead of pork belly!!!!! 
Setting and service is fine but don't recommend Bc of the food
author: Kayla L.

description:
I really love this places food, that's what makes it so hard for me to write a negative review... 
On two separate occasions I've had my order incorrect once by the owner and she insisted that my order was correct and actually argued with me in an attempt to convince me that I made the mistake, it wasn't until the sushi chef told her that it was her mistake that she admitted fault and STILL charged me for something I didn't order.
And tonight I had a similar experience where I placed my order and it was completely incorrect.
The server tried to rectify her mistake but it was too late, I was on a very tight schedule time wise and couldn't wait for a whole new order.
The food is a 10 but the service (servers specially) are some of the worst I've ever had.
author: travis m.

description:
Great service. Great ramen. The pork belly on the ramen was the bomb. I thought the broth was perfect for me although I can see why other reviewers might find it watered down. I don't like extremely salty broths so the one offered in this restaurant was perfect for my taste. I had the Tonkatsu ramen. 

The only disappointment was the soft shell crab roll. It was very greasy and the flavors didn't jive well. 

I'll come back for the ramen if I'm around. 

Parking is hard to find nearby. Unless you are willing to walk a couple of blocks.
author: Melissa C.

description: I ordered tonkatsu ramen, black ramen, and medium spicy with extra corn. The broth was flavorful and bold, but not too thick or creamy.  Not as spicy as I anticipated - which is good! I wasn't overwhelmed by it. The noodles were perfect, along with the soft boiled egg. The meat/charsiu could have been softer (tiny bit tough) but the broth and toppings brought it all together. I'd come back!
author: Adriana N.

description: Came here on a Saturday night and this place has two sides to it ! One side is the ramen side and the other is the sushi side. Either side you can order anything. I got they basic ramen with black garlic which was my first time trying it and it was pretty good ! People there were nice and friendly and it was a casual place.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Pretty good ramen place in SF! I came here on a rainy day with four others, around 1:30pm. This place is a bit small but we only waited about 10 minutes to be seated. I got the Tonkatsu Ramen w/ Pork Belly & Garlic and I really enjoyed the flavor of the broth! It was also interesting to have pork belly w/ my ramen instead of the usual chashu :) The noodles were also a good thickness and as chewy as I like :D I also tasted some of the Curry Ramen and it tasted bomb! I would probably get that one next time :D

The only issue I had was the service was a bit slow. The wait for water and food took longer than we expected. I would still come back for the food though!
author: Sandra N.

description:
Food 5
Presentation 3
Service 5
Ambiance 5

Food was on par with what the city has to offer presentation was lacking a little but not one of my pet peeves, it was strange 4pcs of gyoza versus the normal 6 I would have love to have Takoyaki on the menu but that is personal choice. Service was very attentive and adds to a good review. Yes the family and I would come back.

I hope to change my review to a 5 star on my next visit.
author: C J.

description:
The great thing is that Coco's allows you to make reservations for groups of at least 6. We had 6 in our party and I was pleased to not have to worry about a wait. That said, the table they put us at seats 4 standard Americans or 5 Asian Americans comfortably but the 6th person (me) had to fight for space.

It was a cold evening and warm soup hit the spot. If we're purely judging based on the quality of the ramen, I would not recommend this place. There are much better options in the city. The flavor isn't that authentic and the price is in line with all other places. I had a medium spicy tonkatsu ramen with pork belly and it was just ok. Choose the chashu instead of the pork belly.
author: Yi Z.

description: Literally the best ramen ever. Service was amazing. Atmosphere was adorable and it felt like I was in Asia. Fun music. Gorgeous bowls for the ramen. Broth was perfect consistency.
author: Ella S.

description:
Not a fan. But if you're not looking for ramen ramen and you're OK with fusion ramen that leans heavily on the Chinese side then this could work for you. It reminds me of five spices and Taiwanese beef noodle soup but with ramen noodles. 

Not impressed with the layout of the place--the cold draft from the door made enjoying the meal impossible and the counter spots furthest away from the door (and the draft) sat so high my chin was just barely over the bowl.
author: Yad L.

description: The soup was good the noodles were perfect and the Yaki tori was delish. Definitely will quench your ramen cravings!
author: Nancy K.

description: They shouldn't called themselves as a ramen shop cuz their ramen is not good at all. I would say package ramen taste better. The chachu is tough, the noodle is too hard also. The broth is meh. And their homemade gyoza is bland
author: Ploi S.

description: My friend kept talking about how great the ramen is at this place so I decided to give it a shot... I was disappointed as soon as I walked in when the waitress literally walked past us and did not acknowledge us for the longest time. If your planning on coming here be aware that there is only one waitress trying to do everything at ONCE. And let me tell you, it bugs the **** out of you because you are sitting there waiting to get sat, get your food, and then to get your check. The chicken karage was so greasy and had a lot of dark parts to it in the inside. Its actually disgusting. Not coming back.
author: Valery T.

description:
So-so ramen but great appetizer! 

I had the tonkatsu ramen. It came with your typical ramen toppings, but I was a little disappointed by how the food looked. 

The ramen broth tasted simple and a little bland. The noodle was not too flavorful either. Not too impressed.

We also tried the kabocha appertizer. It is boiled egg wrapped in mashed squash and deep fried. Not sure how Japanese this is but it tasted not bad.
author: Wendy F.

description:
Where do I start, the broth was piss thin, no other flavors except lots lots salt, definitely not something cooked for even more than half hour. This broth is made by mixing powder or other cheap factory premade ingredients. Even I can tell noodle are factory made somewhere else far away, i.e. the same ones you can purchase from gorcery store.

 If this is two dollars ramen in a Japanese train station stand that would made sense. But for people doesn't know anything about ramen, yeah your money and wait time will be wasted, and you are being scammed!
author: sam j.

description:
Came here on a Sunday evening.  It was relatively busy, but we were able to get seated quickly.  We were a party of two and they wanted to seat us at the window bar seats.  The outside neighborhood looked run down and there were some homeless people when we came in so we opted for the inside bar seats.

We enjoyed the pork belly skewers (crunchy and salty in a good way) and karage was good (nothing special, but hard to screw up fried chicken).

I got the Shoyu and hubby got the Tonkotsu.  We both got black garlic add-on, which was good, but I'll probably try without next time to see how flavorful the broth is without it.  I LOVE the egg!  it's got a great consistency and is slightly sweet.  The bamboo was kind of tough.  For the price and neighborhood, I feel it'd be better if they allowed 1-2 free optional add-on rather than charging extra.  

I've heard good things about the seafood and curry ramens so will try those next time!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Found this little gem while driving around San Fran. The tiny place was packed with people so we knew it would be good. This place was great. 

Super nice and friendly staff that made you feel very comfortable. 

Got seated at the bar and didn't have to wait, unlike the peeps who wanted a table. 

My gang order the seafood ramen that you can ask for different levels of spicyness. The shoyu ramen, which had ramen noodles ( duh), bamboo shoots, thinly sliced pork and an interesting deep fry egg... I didn't try that. California rolls ( I know we are SO adventurous when it comes to sushi haha) and the salmon teriyaki, always a great choice. 

Seaweed salad was the bomb, so simple but such delicious nutty flavor to start your meal. 

Great food, super flavorful and good size portions. Waiter and waitress were speedy to attend us and did it pleasantly.
author: Lizzy M.

description: I came here on a Friday night around 8pm. It was pack because the restaurant is very small. We write our name down and waited for 15 minutes before getting seated. I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and my partner ordered the spicy Tonokotsu Ramen. I thought the noodle was either too fascinating nor too bland. It was just alright. I probably will not come back for a second time.
author: Sandy A.

description:
The ramen there is pretty good. The broth is rich and tasty. I got the **Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen w/ pork belly, slow cooked egg and black garlic! FYI, they will ask you if you want black garlic or regular. Black garlic is additional $1. They give you a lot of ramen noodles. Good portion size for meat. The pork belly was very flavorful and tender. Yum! The egg was nicely cooked. I really like the taste of the broth but wish it was just not as oily. On the oily side. But other than that, it was great. Service was good. With a party of 6 or more, its 20% gratuity added. Small restaurant but the wait isn't bad. Recommended. 

My friends and I also got the **Kabocha, its cooked egg surrounded by mashed pumpkin. It was beautifully made but I think it was lacking in flavor. Maybe the pumpkin is not in season? The egg we got was overcooked. Was excited but was a little disappointed with this dish. We also got the **Chicken Karaage. Was not over batter. It's okay, nothing special.
author: Sandy B.

description: We wandered into Coco's today for the first time and it was wonderful. My daughter had the curry ramen and I had the clear and they were both excellent. The restaurant is very kid friendly and charming. We are definitely coming back.
author: Craig Z.

description:
Good ramen, cozy ambiance, reasonable prices.
Had seafood ramen with black garlic, the portion was big enough to fill my stomach.
author: Xavier R.

description: Hands down the best ramen place I have been to so far! I ordered their Miso Ramen at medium spicy with added black garlic. THE BROTH WAS AMAZING. The pork belly also just melts away in your mouth. I don't usually leave reviews, but this place is well worth it! Will definitely be coming back here.
author: Andrea M.

description:
I came here specifically to try their curry ramen ($11.50) which is handwritten into the menu. It's a Japanese curry flavor ramen that feels more like a stew. It isn't thick but comes with stewed root veg - carrots and potatoes - so reminds me of a nice watery stew with chewy yummy ramen noodles. They recommended the pork belly over the chasu because of the stew like tendency and I have to agree that was the way to go. I got the medium spicy but most of the spice was in the broth so the noodles themselves weren't spicy. I only really felt it when I slurped the broth at the end.

I liked the change of pace in ramen flavors a lot. Admittedly I love Japanese curry so it wasn't a stretch for me.
author: Jean K.

description: Walked in, was seated right away. After 15 minutes, we got up and left. 4 empty tables 3 waitresses standing around. I can take a hint but I don't think they can.
author: K W.

description:
I've visited this place 3 times and I think each visit, I grew more and more fond of this place. I'm usually very picky with the texture of my ramen.. I require a thick al dente bite of noodles and I'm glad this place has texture down just right. 

I had a large bowel of the tonkatsu ramen -- mild, with garlic (+1), and extra corn (+2). I'm a big fan of their chasu. It was thick with a deep pork taste, with a hint of sweetness from the char. The bowl is very hearty and easily satisfies a hungry stomach. It's not completely authentic, but it gets the job done if you're craving ramen. 

I wasn't too crazy about the layout of the restaurant. It can get pretty packed with people waiting by the door and cramped with lots of tables in a small venue. The tables were hefty and kinda reminded me of a studying desk. A bit awkward for a ramen spot.
author: Rachelle Y.

description:
Appz: definitely get the kabocha (fried Asian squash w/ a soft boiled egg in the middle) as this is their signature appetizer. It is a little sweet which compliments well with a salty ramen. I would skip the karaage chicken here.

Main course: can't go wrong w/ tonkotsu ramen (black garlic, mild spicy, chashu or pork belly are both solid choices)
author: Tom P.

description: This is my favorite ramen joint in San Francisco.  There are a ton of ramen places in the city that are great.  Some are famous with lines out the door and others are hard to get into and can be pretty pricey.  Not Cocos.  The food is great.  You can always get a seat and the prices are normal.  Take out is great too.  They pack each layer separately so when you get home it tastes fresh after putting it all together.  Their sushi is fresh as well.  Nice spot!
author: Lisa E.

description: My husband took me to here for lunch on Monday.The food is ok not too bad. But I love the Fried Kabocha the most, it was very delicious! I will recommend you to try it!
author: Joyce L.

description: We always love this place - they have really tasty good at great prices.  The place has a personalized small business feel to it - great for lovers of spicy food
author: Piyush G.

description:
A small but great place to grab sushi or ramen. I've heard many times that if you want ramen you have to sit on one side, if you want sushi you have to sit on the other, however, every time my friends and I have gone there, we've always ordered both without issue. 

It does get very busy on any given day and time, so be prepared to wait for a few minutes or so, to be seated. The place is small, so anticipate arriving earlier than you expect to be seated and order. The food is completely worth it! 

They bring you water to your table in a vase so you don't have to keep flagging them down to ask for refills, which is great. The servers are always very kind and helpful. The food is always cooked to perfection and brought out correctly. 

I definitely recommend making this spot your regular dinner meet up with friends and family.
author: Estela D.

description: This was a terrible experience top to bottom, clearly understaffed and service was terrible. The food was very lackluster including the tonkotsu ramen, we found a piece of metal in the monkfish liver dish. Bad bad bad.
author: Ben G.

description:
The Secret to Happiness is their Tonkatsu Black Garlic Pork Belly Extra Extra Spicy Ramen!   It will make your day automatically 100% better. 

Trust me. I know. I've tasted it and I am addicted. 

I recommend all of my friends and neighbours to this place and they've all fallen in love with Coco's Ramen.
author: Peter N.

description:
The BEST Ramen in SF! Beats the ramen places all over Japantown. And oh, the black garlic!!! 

Kudos to Coco!
author: Lise C.

description:
Dinner review. 

Kabocha - 4/5 - Unique 
Squid hands - 3/5

Ramen 
Broth - 2/5
Noodles - 2/5
Chashu - 3/5
Belly - 3/5
Egg - 3/5
Fried egg - 4/5

Overall, some interesting toppings and appetizers but the ramen itself was underwhelming. "I've experienced better."
author: Mark O.

description:
Delicious ramen and really nice service! There was a bit of a wait on a weekday for dinner.

My entire group got the Tonkotsu Ramen with black garlic ($13) and we all loved it. The broth was super rich and the noodles were a perfect texture. The pork belly was amazing! So fatty and flavorful and I loved how soft the boiled egg was. I got mild spicy but next time I would order no spice so I can taste more of the flavors. The gyoza appetizers here were also really tasty.
author: Linda X.

description: I got the miso chashu-ramen with added soft boiled egg, nori and green onion toppings on classic thin noodle. Broth was incredibly flavorful (not oily at all!), noodle textures were great and eggs were cooked to perfection. This bowl of ramen exceeded my expectations and I will most definitely be back! Yum!
author: Lindy M.

description: Cocoa ramen is the BEST ramen place. The ramen is delicious, super flavorful with customizable toppings. If your a vegetarian, the veggie ramen is delicious and has tons of flavor. The sushi is also good, as well as all the appetizers. Would definitely recommend checking this place out.
author: Olvia C.

description:
Mmm.. Ramen does wonders on chilly, late nights. At Coco's, which is situated obscurely on a busy street in Bernal Heights, the ambiance of a small, comfy shop and the only sign that distinguishes this place -- "Ramen" on the front door -- makes this place a unique spot to stop in to.

Seating is only enough for maybe 20 people at one time and it's pretty tight. But for some reason, I'm attracted to this type of dining that I hear are pretty typical in Tokyo. The menu is pretty small, but it offers several types of ramen. My boyfriend and I ordered the tonkotsu and the shoyu (pork & soy-sauce based). The broth wasn't overly salty and the spiciness really hit the spot. I love the way they cooked the pork belly -- tender in the warm broth. Honestly, the ramen is good, but I think the atmosphere does it for me.

It's restaurants like this one that keep SF charming. Again, you won't see anything that says "Coco's Ramen," but instead, there will be a sign that says "Crazy Sushi" that is connected to their ramen shop. Enter in the door with the ramen sign!
author: Vicky N.

description: I'm glad Coco's Ramen is only a block from my work. I came here a few times with my colleagues for lunch and all-staff lunch. If you haven't tried ramen before, this is not your usual Cup-o-Noodle ramen. The soup was flavorful and the toppings are delicious. I had their seafood and tonkotsu ramen before and both are yummy. Prices at $11 - $12.50 is pricier than neighborhoods with more Asian food though. I'm surprise they only have ramen for lunch and not sushi, but it's yummy enough that the restaurant usually has a good lunch crowd.
author: Jennifer T.

description: This place is great!  Their food is excellent. I had their miso ramen and it was delicious!  The flavors were so complex and rich. The ambience of the place was great modern with Japanese style setting, the waitress and chefs nice as well.  Ended chatting up with one of the chefs about ramen because I mentioned I was traveling to Japan. I highly recommend this place. Great ramen!
author: Eddie A.

description: Coco's has the best ramen in San Francisco. Whether we order takeout or dine-in it's always consistent and delicious. Never fails.
author: Tolu B.

description: The spice levels were skewed spicy. If you order medium spice be prepared for spicy. Also the pork shoulder wasn't very tender. Good noodles though. I would NOT recommend the nasu dengaku (eggplant) it was a bit charred and not the right melt-in-your-mouth consistency.
author: Alex P.

description:
Food:

Ton katsu ramen - definitely the type of ramen that I like.  It's a little on the thicker side of noodles and slightly chewy.  The soup wasn't too bad either.

Mochi bacon - I mean come on!  You can't skip out on the mochi bacon!  Bacon wrapped goodness!

Service: very attentive staff and fairly friendly.

Ambiance:  very small place but very neighborhoodish.  You may be seated at a communal table.  

Overall:  not a bad place to go.  I'd be back
author: Spencer Q.

description:
I try not to write a review without going to the joint at least a few times but I just had such a nice experience here that I can't help it. Typical foggy day in the city so I wanted something warm and noodle-y to fill me up. There's around 8 different ramen options here in additional to other Japanese food, so something for everyone. 

There's a bar in the back, so perfect place to sit if you're going alone. I had a nice convo with both the waiters who are very good at their job. 

Ramen curry was not what I was expecting (....so many carrots....) but it wasn't bad. I am not well versed in ramen at all and the waiter gave me some suggestions after a series of embarrassing questions.

Parking is kind of hard (street parking and then residential just the next street back) but I parked in Safeway and walked over. 

There's no sign except for one taped in the window. It's next to crazy sushi. 

Their beer on tap was delicious and light. Perfect when you're almost too full of ramen broth. 

Lots of people getting food to go, so that's an option too!
author: Steph D.

description:
The two stars are for the House Chicken Wings which were perfectly crispy and really tasty.  The Nasu Dengaku was undercooked and underseasoned.  Looks like someone just hacked a hung of eggplant, stuck it in the oven and sprayed some sauce on it, but it was OK.

The real disappointment here was the ramen and that is indeed what we came for.  I was really hoping for more after all the good reviews and the fact this is on some "best ramen" lists.  Noodles were a little mushy, but the real crime here was the Tonkotsu broth.  I'm pretty sure it was not really Tonkotsu - meaning that I'm sure they did not spend hours boiling pork bones to make the broth.  It completely lacked any of the silky creaminess, smokiness or fat that is so indicative of real Tonkotsu.  Instead the broth was thin and watery.  I couldn't even taste any garlic despite paying for the black garlic upgrade (nor were there any garlic pieces, chopped or otherwise).

Service was likewise thin.  We constantly needed to flag down the waiter for everything we needed - utensils, our drinks (completely forgotten), our appetizers (not received until after the ramen), our check, you name it.

So now begins the search for good Ramen in the City.  For now Orenchi in the South Bay reigns supreme.
author: Tarek S.

description:
Was not very impressed with food or the service. We came by on a Sunday night, and it was already pretty crowded. Unfortunately they don't take reservations, so if you go, try to get there early.

SERVICE: 
Accommodating, but not very attentive. The waitress sat us down, then asked us to move 30 mins later so that they could give our table to a larger group. RUDE! Afterwards, we didn't have anyone check on us until it was time to clear our plates and give us the bill.

FOOD:
Tonkotsu ramen - I've had creamier, richer tonkotsu. The broth was spicy and tasty, but I felt it lacked the normal tonkotsu richness. The noodles were nice and al dente. The chashu was good, but on the thicker side. The pork belly is definitely more flavorful but fattier.

Fried Kabocha squash w. egg - This was pretty tasty - basically a soft boiled egg wrapped in kabocha squash and fried, with soy sauce and spicy mayo on top. Yum.

Not sure I would go back for the ramen alone, but a nice option in Bernal.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Mmm! This is my friends and I's current go-to ramen spot in the city! 

I've personally ordered the miso and tonkotsu and was able to grab a bite of the curry and shoyu. All of them were extremely flavorful, delicious and rich! My favorites are definitely the miso and tonkotsu, and I always get it with pork belly (vs. cha sew) and garlic (duh). Their "mild" is a little more mild than usual, so we ask for the spicy sauce/paste on the side. However I don't think it's the same spicy sauce/paste/whatever magic they put in when you do order it mild. (Maybe I'll say "SUPER mild" next time ^_^) Spicy or not, both absolutely delicious! The egg is also amazing and cooked perfectly to my liking! Portions are generous here, but that goes with the price. 

Parking can be frustrating and may feel impossible during evening hours. I've had no problem finding parking during lunch hours though. 

The restaurant may be hard to find, as there is no indicative obvious sign that says, "Coco's Ramen". Use the address listed here and look for a door with a sign that says "Ramen" in not-the-biggest font. Their tiny menu is taped on the side. The restaurant is a little small so seating can be a bit congested depending on which table you get. Bathroom is located at the adjoining sushi restaurant, which I believe they own too. Service is never a problem... they get the job done. 

Yummy ramen! Give this place a try!!
author: Kris C.

description: Had the Shoyu Ramen with Pork Belly. Delicious pork belly, succulent with a tinge of sweetness. The broth was flavorful and light. The noodles still maintained a crunch. Great portion size. I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Sophia T.

description:
Solid four stars! Which is pretty interesting considering I'm really not sure how they'll ever achieve five stars.

Ordered:
Tonkotsu Ramen ($11.50) - Classic ramen, very good pork. So fatty that I literally didn't have to do any chewing, which is how I like my pork! Medium spicy was a good choice for this bowl. And they didn't skimp on the side radishes and stuff, which I appreciate.
Curry Ramen ($11.50) - Literally tastes like Japanese curry, not sure why I was expecting it to taste like anything else... Good flavors if that's your goal!
Fried Cheese ($4) - Kinda like the Japanese version of mozzarella sticks. Cheese sticks rolled in panko? And deep-fried. Served with a sriracha mayo-like sauce. Very heavy...

Quick and friendly service! And window seats are really nice for the people-watching and lighting before sunset. Otherwise the restaurant is pretty dark.
author: Lucy Z.

description: Standard ramen-pretty solid taste and standard price point. A good place to satisfy a ramen craving, but I didn't find it super memorable.
author: Crystal Y.

description: This place is legit.  Has excellent soup base and gives u the option of different spicy levels.  I personally had the tonkatsu with chashu and it was very flavorful.  Its cery rare for me to finish all the soup for my ramen but i did this time around.  Would definitely go here again!
author: Calvin H.

description: I wouldn't know how the food was because we left before we could order. Sat us in the corner then proceeded to forget about us for 15 minutes. Terrible service, what a shame.
author: Victor G.

description:
I came with a friend for a late lunch so there wasn't a wait! Definitely a plus.  Service was great, servers were very friendly and liked the atmosphere.  

I got the curry ramen with black garlic and pork belly.  It was delicious! I was expecting a really thick slurry, but it was actually soup with curry flavor! There were also carrots and potatoes which had curry stuck to it which was delicious! Definitely recommend it! The pork belly was super flavorful and tender as well! 

My friend got the tonkotsu and she couldn't finish it cause it was so much! She really enjoyed the broth,but I had to help her and my initial reaction was that it was different than most tonkotsu broths I've had.  It wasn't as heavy which is a good thing!

I'd recommend this place to others!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Been kind of a go to spot for me when I'm in the Bernal Height / Mid-Mission neighborhood.  They fill a bit of a void combining Ramen, Sushi, Appetizer, and cooked food around here.  I do hit up the other restaurants around Fumi, Kama & Tekka several times within the immediate radius but they just fall a bit short to my liking.  Fumi is lesser in food a bit crude, Kama is too snobby in service giving not willing to accommodate to customer's needs, Tekka House is a bit noisy with loud music - too hip to relax.

I set the bar high for Japanese food, so I'm not going to say Coco's food is over the top.  It is just about on par more like a 3.5*.  But I'll bump them up due to the friendlier servce.  The food fluctuates a bit a times.  The Ramen taste kind of right, the Sashimi is reasonably fresh, Sushi and Appetizers is adequate, the price is acceptable.  Again, it's a neighborhood spot, I can see the efforts but there isn't a culinary genius here and nothing out of the norm.

The big draw for me here is the staff is down to earth, friendly and willing to address the customers need more or less.  That actually works for me if I am to frequent a place.
author: Steven C.

description: Delicious! So far one of my top 3 spots to get ramen in the city. Just continuously typing to make this a review instead of a tip
author: Sodro K.

description:
My friend initially wanted to check out Orenchi Beyond but after reading it's inconsistent reviews and reading Coco's more impressive reviews, decided to give this place a try and I don't regret the decision.

Coco's ramen earns their four stars.  I don't think it's me who has the same ramen dilemma, but I've never been to a ramen place in SF that really hits the spot until I've tried coco.  I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen with pork belly, cooked egg, and black garlic.  This generous portion of ramen had me sweating like I was at a sauna.  Had to take off my glasses because they were fogging up quite a bit.

My friend ordered the same thing but ordered double braised pork belly with twice as much pork as I had.  Wish I had done the same as the pork belly was cooked to perfection and was so tender with just the right amount of pork fat for flavoring.

We also shared the kabocha which is a boiled egg wrapped around pumpkin mush and deep fried.  Definitely recommend trying it with the sauce.  It was surprisingly big enough to split among two people.

Been to a few ramen places (some a hit, some a miss) in Japan and I'll even dare say that Coco's ramen is comparable to the good ramen places in Tokyo.  I had to knock it down a star because it's quite pricey for a bowl when you amp it up with more ingredients including extra $2 charge for black garlic.  Ended up about $20 for bowl of ramen which is about $10 more than what you can currently get in Japan.  And everyone used to say how expensive Japan is!
author: Bailey N.

description: Two stars because the Kobacha was very tasty, although the egg was overcooked. Tonkotsu ramen was bland and mediocre. Appetizers came out way after the ramen 10 minutes apart. I let them know we were disappointed in the service, to which no rectification was made. I wanted to make this a regular spot, but the food and service was disappointing. They were nice, but wasn't worth the money.
author: Kyle S.

description: Loved the Veggie Ramen! It was the perfect portion and hotness. The noodles were al denté which complimented the broth. It's truly light and yummy
author: Nadine B.

description: Awesome Ramen; very friendly staff; great local spot
author: Kris F.

description:
Super cute place. I was unimpressed by the name on the sign, but Coco's Ramen proved I shouldn't judge a book by its cover. The indoors decor resembled that of an izakaya, mahogany wooden furniture and red lanterns with japanese on them. They offer a good selection of reasonably priced sake and beer as well.

Ramen: 4 stars
Yakitori: 2 stars
Ambience: 4 stars

The tonkatsu ramen ($11ish) didn't disappoint, not too salty. Well-cooked ramen too. I would say somewhat mediocre in terms of presentation and the accompanying garnishes, but the flavor was great. The yakitoris however were a waste of money. We got the gyu-tan (beef tongue) and chicken. Chicken tasted like teriyaki chicken from yoshinoya, and gyu-tan came in 3 sad little pieces. Not worth $5 at all. 

Anywho, still felt this was a hidden gem and deserves another try! Good neighborhood eats :)
author: Maggie G.

description: I find myself comparing other ramen places I visit to Coco's. I visit frequently when I'm in the mood for ramen which seems to be once every two weeks. Service is friendly and  efficient. Since I'm not a strict pescatarian the closest I get to having their tonkatsu ramen is by ordering the veggie ramen BUT switching out the veggie broth for the tonkatsu broth and get this, for no extra charge! I'm addicted to the broth. It is authentic, pork bone broth with that umami flavor and it is sooooooo gooood! Don't forget to  top off your ramen with the black garlic oil! Spicy is not that spicy, go medium for a kick or extra spicy for real spicy.
author: Mona C.

description:
Based on everyone else's reviews I know you're going to get the Tonkotsu pork belly ramen.  Which is f*cking fantastic!  But let me also encourage you to add a slow cooked egg (or even two) to that and if you like sweet smooth cheap sake get a bottle of the Kurosawa Nigori.

Full disclosure: the egg was life changingly good one time and just "OK" the second.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Came with a friend for dinner and there was barely anyone here! (note that it was a weekday, don't really know if that makes a difference) but we were so happy we didn't have to wait!

I ordered the tonkotsu ramen (no spice because I'm a baby) with pork belly & garlic and my friend ordered miso ramen - mine  came with bamboo, green onions, egg and seaweed (I'm pretty sure its the same for miso). You can definitely taste the difference between the two - both equally flavorful! 

Service was alright - there as no refill on water until I tracked down a waiter...
author: Carrie L.

description: Coco's ramen is the best ramen in San Francisco.  Maybe in CA
author: Reid H.

description:
Whoa delicious! One of the best ramen places in the city by far. The broth was perfect. 

Came by on a Friday night around six pm. The place was packed already but luckily we were able to get two seats at the bar. Soon after the line was long. Come early! Also parking isn't too easy to find either but we were lucky to find a spot by Safeway.The place is next to Crazy Sushi, which is also owned by them. 

I ordered the shio ramen with chashu, garlic, and an extra slow cooked egg for $2 and no spiciness while my friend ordered the tonkatsu ramen with pork belly and also got an extra egg. The ramen came with half an egg already which we didn't realize we would get. I got to try both broths and decided that I liked the tonkatsu better as it was more flavorful. My friend complained that the portions were small, but we were full by the end of our meal. Next time I'll try the miso and get pork belly over chashu.
author: Christina G.

description:
REVIEW #500. Thanks to my meticulous Yelping along with an obsessive compulsive gravitation towards ramen, I stumbled across Coco's: a horrifyingly unauthentic name for a Japanese restaurant, and an intriguingly nondescript storefront in which the only sign is a paper on the door with ramen written in wispy brushstrokes. 

The kabocha is likely the best appetizer in existence, ever. It's a soft-boiled egg enveloped in mashed pumpkin, and fried for a thin crispy coating.... in this era with such crayziness over runny eggs and pumpkin spice lattes, need I say more. It's a bit pricey at ~$10, but it is a glowing bomb of deliciousness (FYI it literally glows if you sit at the bar stools by the windows around sunset).
