The ramen is also quite good, and the way they arrange the toppings is exceptionally photogenic (t's disappointing when delicious ramen decides to humbly present itself on Instagram as a bowl of soup with a lonely mound of noodles). We tried the miso and shoyu, both of which turned out to be excellent broths: I suggest getting it spicy and with black garlic for an extra kick, because they don't charge extra for spicy and black garlic isn't available at all ramen places.

In short, I'd say their ramen is goldilocks style, i.e. just right. The broth has just the right amount of creamy richness, the various toppings in just the right ratio to complement the noodles, and overall striking just the right balance of flavors and textures. I was initially disappointed at the half an egg and single slice of the (heavenly melt-in-your-mouth) chashu, but it turned out to be just the right portion to leave you satisfied but not feeling fat and hypernatremic and volume overloaded (cue RAAS).

To complete the dining experience, the ambiance is cool: an authentic, Tumblr-worthy Japanese decor with a classy dark theme and wooden tables that make an excellent backdrop for food porn. The silly cow-shaped pepper shaker adds an amusing and unforgettable finishing touch. Service is polite and efficient, and they didn't rush us even though we stayed for over half an hour after we finished eating (I was stuck in a conference call... dinner took way longer than I had expected because we were absolutely enthralled by the kabocha and cut it up in artsy presentation) (don't ask).

The only downside of Coco's? No space in the stomach afterwards for Mitchell's Ice Cream around the corner :x
author: Edna C.

description:
Pretty true to japan ramen and an awesome kabocha ball. 

Was hesitant because this place is in the same restaurant as a not so great rated sushi place. Definitely was happy with the result though. Really tasty ramen, good service, and a surprise that their kabocha ball was absolutely incredible (and seriously huge, that thing is for like 4 people).
author: Ryan B.

description:
I have been here twice. I decided to choose this spot for a great evening of ramen. Let me tell you about my experience. I went with a few people including my sister, who had an amazing time ordering food. 

When she asked how spicy "medium" was, the server said "Hmmm, if 1-5... 3?" LOL ISN'T THAT AMAZING. Of course the medium is the middle of 1-5. 

The food arrived and overall it wasn't too bad, I enjoyed my food and the service was okay. I'm giving this review a medium.
author: Matthew C.

description: I live near Coco's and go here whenever I want ramen but am too lazy to trek over to Mensho or Nojo. I usually get the spicy miso or tonkatsu with an extra egg. The broths are rich, but taste like they use a lot of MSG.
author: Jean L.

description: We ordered the chicken and pork broth, medium spice. I ordered with black garlic but couldn't tell a difference. The spice really hits you once you start drinking the broth. It was tasty, but not mind blowing. The noodles were good, nice and thick and a little firm. Good portions as well. I would recommend trying out this place.
author: Philip D.

description:
This place is OK...
It's owned by Chinese, so if you are looking for a Japanese owned ramen place, for authenticity or whatever, this is not place.
Their ramen is not the best nor the worst in the city. Having tried a number of taken place recently, I would say it's right in the middle.
You do have the option of choosing pork belly instead of chashu, which is nice.
author: Smual S.

description: Decent ramen but nothing special. Karaage seemed to be made of chicken scraps but was still tasty.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Went here because of the reviews and s recommendation. Unfortunately my friend and I didn't have a good experience. The people were nice, but the atmosphere is very rushed. Food was not as good as I have had it at other places
author: David H.

description:
There was quite a wait at 6:15 on a Thursday night. FYI the sign in sheet is right behind the door for any first timers. There was a bunch of people standing by the door so it was hard to figure out where it was.
I ordered the Spicy Shoyu Ramen w/pork belly ($11.50). So YUMMY! The husband ordered the Miso Ramen w/chashu ($11.50). 
For how busy they were, service was pretty good. They got us everything we needed in a timely manner. They were attentive enough where we were able to get their attention fairly easily. Definitely a place we would return to.
author: D V.

description:
I've been here a number of times - the ramen quality is mediocre at best/service being short of desired. It's one of the only ramen joints near the area so perhaps this explains why it gets crowded during meal times. But the crowd is not indicative of its actual quality/whether it's worthwhile. 

Service was not good - they put 2 random extra things on my check and didn't even apologize when I pointed it to them that they've made this mistake. 

I asked for "no meat" and the lady gave me two slabs of pork (thanks?). I ordered the Shoyu Ramen both times I've been there and neither times did I walk away thinking that was worth whatever $13 they charge you for the small bowl. 

Find somewhere else to go. You're in SF after all.
author: Wei W.

description:
When i leaned over my 3 portions of Ebi Nagiri my head whipped back from the strong fish smell, but I decided to take a bite anyways. The bite ended up in a tissue. Being real hungry I then barely managed to muscle down my mongo/avocado roll before I felt ill and needed to visit the washroom twice. We had to pay in a rush so I can leave the restaurant. 
The waitress never inquired if we liked our meal and never noticed the 6 bright orange shrimp pieces, minus a bite, just sitting there, uneaten. We paid in a hurry, but before we left I told the waitress, while pointing to my uneaten food, that clearly, I didn't like that food and I thot the shrimp smelled bad and tasted old. She said she will "ask the manager" and I heard her report my words to the person behind the counter. This person shrugged, turned his back and proceeded to ignore me. We left. My husband left a 15% tip. End of story.
It is one thing to serve stinky shrimp, but to exhibit zero concern when the customer is willing to pay for not eating their order is downright upsetting and rude. I wish we never stumbled into that place.
author: Mia L.

description:
Asininely slow service and oblivious hosts make getting your order in or acquiring a glass of water an epic task. Luckily, large portions and a tasty broth make up for it.

Vibe-wise, it's a cozy spot that'll get the job done whether you're on a date or just squeezing in a bite at the end of the day.

Some have claimed the spicy to be too spicy, but I felt the spicy was quite mild. So bring your hunger game and maybe a book if you happen to come on a night where they decide to staff one poor waiter for a full house.
author: Anthony N.

description:
It was a rainy day in san Francisco last president day my last night staying in san Francisco. my friend and i wanted to try out ramen we went to mission district and saw this ramen place.

It was a small spot so waited about 45 mins for table for two had to wait another 30 mins to get our food out. I totally understand that its a small place and a holiday but i just dont get why only two people working on that shift on a holiday?

All in all the food is amazing, just the service.
author: Kirt V.

description: Great meal, friendly service. Miso ramen very close to what I've recently had in Kyoto. Love this little authentic place!
author: Jarrett P.

description:
Ate lunch here with a co-worker (when we found Fumi Curry Resto down the street closed on a Monday) and was pleasantly surprised by how good their Shoyu Ramen tasted!  Much better tasting than many of the more popular ramen in SF!  

I opted for the pork belly (which is no extra charge), garlic, and no spiciness.  The soft-boiled egg and noodles were excellent.

As for the space itself, it's pretty hole-in-the-wall.  The tables and benches remind me of an old Asian grandmother's house.  I sat on a bench and I was almost "towering" over my co-worker who sat in a regular chair across from me lol (we're the same height). We arrived around 11:30 am on a weekday and there was no wait, but at noon, the place began to quickly fill up.
author: Ana Marie L.

description: Good ramen for the price. Had the spicy miso, the broth was very rich and the noodle were cooked perfectly. The service was also great which is always a plus.
author: Aymeric M.

description:
I searched yelp for Ramen in San Francisco because Mark wanted Ramen for his birthday. Many were only open for dinner, so since we were making plans for lunch, Coco's Ramen was the winner. I also liked that it was close to Bernal Heights Park. I brought my camera so we could make an afternoon of it. 

Mark ordered the Shoyu Ramen. Heat options were spicy, spicy spicy and very spicy. Mark got spicy spicy. He absolutely loved it. I had a taste. It was too spicy for my taste, but I will say it was a flavorful spicy. It was not just hot for the sake of making it hot. I appreciated the attention to creating something special. 

I ordered the grilled squid. It came with spicy mayo and a broth-like sauce. The squid was tender, not too chewy and had a nice smoked flavor. A touch of each dipping sauce added just the right flavor, leaving the squid as the star. The tentacles, which according to Wikipedia are called arms, were especially delicious. They had more of a char from the grill and boy were they tasty!

The restaurant seems to be run by a husband and wife. She was very kind and helpful and he assisted with delivering meals to the table as the lunch crowd began to pick up. 

Free parking on a side street on a Friday at 11:30 was very easy to find.
author: Scott N.

description:
Came here on a Friday night with a group of my friends (party of 7) around 7:00pm. It is a small restaurant and it was quite busy. Put our name down and waited about 20 mins and we had 4 people and was still waiting for a few people to come. The waitress was nice and let us sit down first while our friends were looking for parking. The have a few tables and bar seatings. 

We ordered the gyoza , chicken karaage , kabocha appetizer (mashed pumpkin with an egg inside) it could use a little bit more flavor. We were excited to try this but was disappointed. The egg inside was overcooked. I got the spicy tonkotsu ramen (med) with pork belly (flavorful and tender). Portions are generous (ramen noodles and pork belly) I wasn't able to finish all the food. It also came with an egg, bean sprouts and bamboo shoots. I added the black garlic ($1 more) but could have left it out, made the broth a little bit too oily. Ramen was really tasty and flavorful but wasn't super spicy. Recommend this place if you're in the area and feel like eating ramen. 

*if you have a party of 6 or more, you can make reservations on their website 6 hours before your party.
author: Vanessa M.

description:
This place did not disappoint. Opened just a few months ago, this place has still remained a hidden gem amongst the locals. I went with a friend and there was no wait on a Saturday night at 7PM. Awesome, right?

Please order the House Chicken Wings. You will not regret it. Just do it. No questions asked. DELICIOUS! Plus, they were definitely different than your usual chicken wings -- drum sticks -- and what not. Unique and weird shape. Definitely caught me off guard!

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and it was amazing. Medium spicy. Pork Belly. Black garlic. The whole package. For a ramen place, this place gave a fairly amount of portions. They didn't bother skimping out on the meat either or the noodles. 

Broth was FLAVORFUL. MMMHMM. Just pure yum! I definitely enjoyed this. It was very hearty too and thick, which was good for me. Tip: Ramen is a great meal after drinking ;). 

The toppings were good. The soft boiled egg was cooked right too. No complaints here.

Thumbs up to you, Coco Ramen! You are definitely a top ramen place in SF for me and I can't wait to take my friends to your awesome establishment! Hopefully.. there won't be a long wait the next time I go! :)
author: Chinsin S.

description: Such a let down!!! Waited about 15-20 minutes to be seated. Ordered the tonkatsu with pork belly and added black garlic. Noodles were super al'dente. Broth was kind of oily; was it the pork belly or the black garlic??? Soft-boiled egg was good. Overall "meh", definitely had better. If you're wondering... there's no need to try it. Save it for the Mission yuppies and gentrifiers!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Most people don't think "hey, it's the middle of summer - you know what I want? soup!" but this is San Francisco in the summer we're talking about, and Karl is in full effect so soup is most-definitely a year-round option.

I thought Coco's interior was nice - red and blacks* gave it a very traditional Japanese look, easily shattered by the Diet Coke I ordered.

Drinks arrived quickly and ramen came very quickly afterward. I had the miso option with an extra egg** and both the chashu and pork belly because, why not?

Probably too much food for one person when you put those additions in, but the broth was nice and salty though the chashu didn't have a ton of flavor.

Came here at 1pm on a weekday so it wasn't too crowded; Bernal Heights is primarily an evening area and not as slammed during the day.

*- which always works for University of Georgia fans like myself.
author: Danny P.

description: Avoid unless you want food poisoning. I have been ill with food poisoning for the last 4-5 days since I ate there Thursday night. The pain, constant restroom run, chills, sweating, fever and dehydration was definitely not worth it. I use to love going to Coco Ramen, but I will most definitely never come back. Please keep your food clean so other people don't have to suffer like me.
author: Linda L.

description: This is my go to ramen place. I keep trying to find different ramen places that compare and so far I have found none. I order the tonkatsu with pork belly and it is the most delicious thing ever. It's a small place so seating may take a while depending on the night and how many people you take, but it is worth it!
author: Brenda S.

description:
Ok, first off, anyone claiming authenticity here are brand new SF transplants trying ramen for the first time or think they know ramen cause they saw Anthony Bourdain eat some while in some white suburbs.

This place is NOT authentic. It was accurately described by another yelper as FUSION. For example, they serve their fried oysters with a sweet viscous chili sauce that is a Vietnamese staple, a sauce Japanese would never go near. 

They used a generic "curry powder," like a generic Mcormick style one found at Safeway or Walmart, to do their "curry ramen" (which I regretfully ordered.....BIG mistake..I should have known better, I know.....Not authentic in the first place just to have this on their menu).

My wife got the seafood ramen, also very un-ramen like, which was also a huge mistake. Ironically we followed yelp suggestions.

The broth literally tasted like it just came out of a can - so light. This is not Yamadeya's 12-hour (or is it 24?) cooked pork bone broth, no effin way. This is not the rich lusciousness of Ken Ken ramens broth. This is not the cohesiveness and flavor of Tanpopos broth. Don't even start with ramen underground. All these blow Coco away. 

All in all, a gigantic disappointment that reaffirms that most people on yelp have no valid culinary opinion. 

Also, I ordered a beef tongue yakitori. It was cold and meager: 2 skewers that were about 4 inches long each, each with 2 of the smallest and thinnest beef tongue shavings I've ever seen. It didn't even have any kind of grill or bbq flavor. Seriously? 

Looking at the crowd here, I should have known better; ALL hip people, too hip for me, coming here for god knows what reason, pushing and shoving to pile into this just-remodeled SF transplant trap rocking too-tight clothes.

Get me outta here!!!!
author: Max G.

description:
I don't know which search is more desperate to me: finding great menudo or great ramen. Both can get pretty elusive if you ask me. One brings out collective groans from tripe-haters, while the other attracts the palate of every Asian in this city between the ages of 22 and 35. You would think I was looking for the former since I was on the 14-Mission past Cesar Chavez, but no, I was looking for this new spot off 29th Street right next to Crazy Sushi, another place that never caught my eye or wallet. Sure enough, it's the same owner who has decided to jump on the ramen bandwagon. So naturally I had to try it on a cold wintry night when I needed a bowl of noodles to comfort my soul.

Their signage consisted of a piece of paper taped to the front door (photo: http://bit.ly/1strz6g). Even though it was half-empty, I was relegated as a solitary diner to the little two-seat counter facing the front window, not the most comfortable spot in the place but at least I had it to myself. It should come as no surprise that I selected the $11.50 Tonkotsu Ramen, my personal favorite, even though seven varieties are offered. But first, some appetizers were necessary. OK, 'necessary' is an overstatement. I was just hungry from the long bus ride. I ordered the $8 Fried Oysters, which I thought were a bit overpriced for four semi-plump pieces as good as they were.

They came with some sweet-and-sour sauce which I didn't like much (photo: http://bit.ly/1C1EU5l) since I would have preferred a spicy aioli. Regardless, the bigger disappointment was the $5 Beef Tongue Yakitori, two skewers each with thinly sliced, barely there tongue nicely grilled but just so paltry in portion as to force me to surmise that I was given a child's portion (photo: http://bit.ly/1xjFtDr). They were gone in ninety seconds, I swear. At last, the Tonkotsu Ramen arrived. Now what was interesting is that they offer what kind of broth finish you want, so I ordered the black garlic based on a variation I tried at the Ramen Shop over in Oakland. But more strangely, I don't believe pork chashu was a complimentary topping.

It didn't matter so much in my case because I automatically ordered the double braised pork belly for an extra $3.50, but I would have been bummed if my carnivery was meant to be satisfied merely by the pork broth. The other ingredients, however, were all present and accounted for: the soft-boiled egg half, bamboo shoots, shredded vegetables, and nori (photo: http://bit.ly/1BgRNdV). The broth certainly had a palpable kick to it, and I just asked for medium. There's no telling what happens when the spiciness moves up a few notches. The texture of the noodles were reasonably al dente, so all was still right with the world. Although service was fairly attentive bordering on unctuous, I'd still place this bowl somewhere in the middle of the pack. Guess I could still look for menudo around these parts, I guess.

FOOD - 3 stars...reasonably good ramen has quite a kick but little else of distinction, especially a red mark for the paltry portions on the appetizers
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...pretty standard space as ramen houses go...some more real seating for solitary diners would be nice
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...pretty enthusiastic
TOTAL - 3 stars...a mixed bag at best as this entry into the city's ramen sweepstakes, still needs tinkering
author: Ed U.

description:
My first bowl of ramen in a looonnnnggg time. Stopped here for lunch (location is hard to miss if you're not looking for it!).

Restaurant was still pretty empty so we were quickly seated and our orders were taken. I ordered the Shoyu Ramen with black garlic, medium spiciness, and chashu. My favorites parts of this meal were the egg and the broth! Was a little disappointed by the 2 tiny pieces of chashu. Ramen itself was perfectly cooked and had the perfect amount of gooeyness to its texture. Will definitely return. Not sure if the extra charge for the black garlic makes a difference? Will have to try without it next time!
author: Yin H.

description:
I came for dinner on a Friday night and a wait had formed by the time we left around 8pm. Keep in mind, the restaurant is small. Most folks came in pairs, or as a sizable group which they can accommodate by putting their tables together. Per Coco's website, they take reservations for parties with 6 to 8 people. 

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen ($11.50), medium spicy, and added pork belly (+$3.50) and black garlic (+$1). My favorite parts of the bowl were the al dente noodles, the perfectly cooked soft boiled egg, and the tender and flavorful pork belly. The broth was unlike one I've had before and wasn't your typical creamy, porky tonkotsu broth. It was still savory and tasty nonetheless. The bamboo shoots were a let down. They tasted like they came straight out of the can and weren't treated so the shoots had that intense musty bamboo flavor.  

We also ordered the grilled whole squid app ($12) which arrived to our table after our bowls of ramen. The ramen came out pretty fast but I would have preferred the meal to start with the appetizer and the noodle soup bowls to follow at a reasonable pace. The squid was served with a ponzu sauce and a spicy mayo sauce. For me, the flavor of the spicy mayo sauce was like nacho cheese. Not a bad thing but just different. While the squid wasn't overcooked, it could have been grilled longer for a more intense flavor and to add some charred texture to the squid. 

Food price tags were a bit hefty but service was very friendly. If you have any questions about the food or sake menu, they are more than happy to answer them. Coco's Ramen is connected to Crazy Sushi so if you need to use the restroom, you'll be asked to walk through Crazy Sushi and use the bathroom on the other side.
author: Maya S.

description:
I've been coming here about once a week for the last two years. Actually, to be honest, I'll sometimes eat at Coco's two or three times in a given week. Don't tell anyone though because that's somewhat embarrassing. But it gives you an idea of how good the ramen is. Seriously. It's that good.

Coco's serves a variety of different styles of ramen, ranging from the classic shoyu (soy) to the more flavorful curry. The curry ramen is this reviewer's personal favorite (made spicy with pork belly), but you really can't go wrong with any of the choices on the menu. Each ramen dish has its own distinct robust flavor. All are served hot in a giant bowl with a variety of different ingredients (egg, noodle, vegetables, etc.).

Both Eater SF and SFist put Coco's Ramen at the top of the pack for San Francisco ramen joints.

Rest assured, you will walk out of Coco's with your belly filled to the brim.

Tip: Coco's Ramen's ramen served spicy is the best sinus decongestant one can find anywhere. Seriously. Anywhere.
author: Chris G.

description: AMAZING!! The first ramen place I found that has a vegetarian option (maybe I need to do better research) but this was perfect. They put so much tofu,corn, and seaweed for my veggie ramen I was so happy since I had never been to a place with that option. My partner ordered their chicken teriyaki plate and he seemed satisfied with it, even though in my opinion it was pretty pricy for the size of the plate but he liked it! I will definitely be coming back for that veggie ramen!!!
author: Mellany Q.

description:
Worst bowl of ramen I have ever had.  Got the shoyu garlic broth with no spice and chasu and his was miso garlic no spice and chasu as well.  The waiter seemed a bit confused when I said mild initially and then I just decided on no spice at all.  

After a little bit our bowls came out.  I noticed mine had literally only like two bean sprouts with some seaweed while his had a handful.  My broth was so bland, like it tasted like a water broth with just some orange food coloring.  His miso had a tad bit of flavor but was watery as well.  The egg was pretty much the only good thing in the bowl.  Some of the noodles were clumped together and seemed almost package like.  Also one pork slice was a lot more tender than the other one in my bowl.  A good noodle soup is based on the noodles and the broth, none of which were done well at all.  The sad thing is I feel like they probably use MSG (from the way my tongue felt afterwards) yet the broth had no taste.  The portions were on the smaller side too, and I wouldn't mind if they were smaller and that high priced if the quality was actually there.  $11.50 for each bowl, so disappointing!  When I got home, I ate my husband's leftover French fries from lunch, though they were cold, they were still more appetizing than our ramen. 

Service wasn't bad but wasn't friendly either.  They just seemed to be going through the motions.  It's tiny and maybe just gets a lot of business from being the only ramen place in the general area.  Us and one other Asian couple were the only Asians in the restaurant.  Coco Ramen is Cantonese owned as well.
author: Cat C.

description:
This is a review based on the Ramen, only.
I was excited to try a new Ramen spot, but the Ramen here is not as clean as other places. 
It seemed as though broth is a little too thick with extra flavoring. The noodles were good, pork belly tender, and I liked the fact that my Curry Ramen had potatoes in it. 
Might come back to try the sushi, but have had better Ramen!
author: Diandra S.

description: One of my top choices when it comes to ramen in San Francisco! My favorite places are in San Mateo, and when I don't want to drive all the way over there Coco is my go-to! I order the Ramen Tonkatsu with garlic and rotate between pork belly and chasu. Can't go wrong with either. The only bad thing about this place is the size of the restaurant! It's pretty small and there's always a wait. Try to go when it first opens!
author: Kelly S.

description:
I used to work at a ramen place and I enjoyed the ramen here even more. We went on a Saturday night at dinner time so there was a little bit of a wait but we did not mind. There was a waiting list on the back of the door that we wrote our name on. There wasn't much room to wait so we waited outside most of the time.

The servers were super friendly and attentive. I got the tonkatsu ramen and my friend got the shoyu ramen both were very flavorful and came with a fair amount of meat and lots of noodles. They have a spiciness scale for their ramen and really like spicy food so I got my ramen spicy, next time I would get extra spicy though. We also got the chicken kaarage appetizer and it was perfect to share between two people. Overall it was a good ramen experience!
author: Andrea M.

description:
as a dude who lived in Japan and knows a thing or "more" on ramen I know what am saying. 

Good: price, service, location
Bad: noodles is not authentic, its what you find in a plastic version. Everytime i see this, I already know its not good. Broth is bland. Meat is just ok.

A Ramen place should be run an authentic or expert "ramen" cook. Japanese or taught by Japanese. Im asian so no racism here. I go to Ajisen in San Mateo (by far the best, value wise ramen shop) and their cooks are latinos but its hella great! 
The other Japanese shop almost beside it suffers from meh, blah ramen...their curry is good though. 
So, pls Coco's, learn from the masters! Japanese ramen is like a sacred ritual for them like rice. Do not make ramen any other style, taste, look etc... Japanese only.
author: Archie K S.

description:
If you are driving on the mission looking for this place good luck finding it, passed by it 4 times, if your walking you will find it alot easier, let break down what I sampled and how it faired

some of the appitizers we shared included these items:

pork belly - can't say no to the pork belly, must order!! you will probably have to order 3 servings of these to get full if not 5 servings haha but it is literally thick cut bacon not to salty, just made perfect

bacon wrapped mochi salty sweet, slightly odd pairing for me salty taste of the bacon, then the wrapped mochi in the middle was pasty not the mochi you buy at the stores with filling in the middle of green tea or strawberry, plain just doughy type not filling, I would order it again, not my favorite but yes I would order it again

kobocha -yase!!! what tasted like pumpkin outer layer with hard boiled egg in the middle how they do this is a mystery, it is fairly big to share with 3 people just to sample it, it is worth a try.

tonkotsu ramen add black garlic medium spicy; ramen wise it was ok, the noodles were springy doesn't taste like it was a cup of noodle brands like some other places, actually tasted more on the fresh side, the broth was creamy and semi spicy, broth to me is king of good ramen, theirs interpretation was good, not my favorite but I would come back and sample other bowls, for the Tonkotsu though passing grade.

food *** overall passing, pork belly is a must, kobocha is more of a must try cause it looks interesting, the ramen is ok
price $$
service **** very helpful and friendly staff
ambiance **** dark, romantic like feel inside, mind you it was dinner will all guys hahhaha but yeah you get the dark room with a candle in the middle of the table type feel meant for couples, not to sway you from coming in, it was modern interpretation, I liked the design and look from the inside

parking on the mission sucks, allow yourself 30 min to look for parking
author: Clarence A.

description:
Reading about Winter Storm Juno makes me so happy and grateful I live on the West Coast (Best Coast). In comparison, 65 degree weather is pretty warm compared to their 27 degree weather... right? Not for this SoCal-weather-kind-of-girl! I need it to be warm and sunny enough to wear my oversized sunglasses, tank top, and short shorts. Every. Single. Day! Unfortunately, life is unfair. So I'll take the next best thing, which is staying warm by eating a hot bowl of ramen on a winter day. 

I've never ventured around the Bernal Heights neighborhood before, so when my friend said he wanted to try a new ramen joint, I was game! 

The store itself is pretty small - it can probably fit 30-40 people. The decor is VERY Asian. There are Asian paintings on the wall. And the furniture looks like it came out of, well, my grandparents' living room. It's also a mom and pops store, so service might be on the slower side since only two people are working. Our lunch here was way longer than I expected because they seemed to have forgotten us since we sat at the window seats by the door. 

Tonkotsu Ramen ($11.50) - Rich Tonkotsu base with Pork and Chicken Stock
- choice of garlic, no garlic, or black garlic, and spiciness

Good portion that satisfied my hunger. The noodles were cooked perfectly, and the broth was quite flavorful. Solid ramen place!
author: Christine S.

description:
One of my favorite ramen spots in the city. Very authentic food and ambience. Rich and creamy broth and noodles - yum! Also like the mix of ramen and yakitori (skewer) options. Menu items most enjoyed:

+ tonkatsu ramen with chashu pork
+ calamari
+ pork belly yakitori
+ beef tongue yakitori (nice and tender if you're adventurous!)

Wasn't as big a fan of the miso ramen. Will return to try the other ramen broth flavors.
author: Michelle E.

description:
Good ramen, but mediocre service. Only one waiter and understandably you will be busy, but one can still treat customers nicer.  When looking at the menu, we noticed the page listing the ramen and next to it said "spiciness".  The waiter comes to jot down our order and I ask him what "spiciness" meant.  "10", he says.  uh... "so what is your question?"  he seemingly asked with a sarcastic tone.  Someone else then reiterates  the question and he explains that "spiciness" meant the level of spiciness of your broth (spiciness level 1-10, 1 = zero spicy). We all could've saved time had he clarified it the first time.  Anyways, my party and I put in our ramen order,  adding a couple of sides.

when the orders arrive, there was a mistake in one order (gave us chashu instead of pork belly) and the waiter was kind to comp us the pork belly, which by the way is delicious:  very tender meat with the fat layer melting in your mouth. as I said, ramen is good, though soup is a little oily.  It's 3 stars for the food, and the redemption on the correcting the order.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Coco's Ramen is a sister restaurant of Crazy Sushi which is right next door, and there is actually an opening in the wall inside that you can go back and forth the two restaurants inside. I have never tried Crazy Sushi; and just by looking at these two names I knew their food must not be related to the words "authentic Japanese" at all - well I was right about this part, but surprisingly Coco's Ramen is unauthentically good!

Coco's is located in the intersection of Bernal Height / Mission / Noe Valley neighborhood. Kind of a hipster area. Went on Sunday evening, wasn't expecting any wait since it's pretty new but I ended up waiting for almost 45 mins. Couple reasons:

1. Restaurnt is quite tiny, less than 35 seats.
2. I guess the servers are still super new and they were pretty bad at tasks management - there was clearly a line outside and we saw at least 8 people finished their meals and left the restaurant, but the tables were left unclear and they couldn't sit people in.

Task management aside - the service was pretty nice. Both servers were very polite and very willing to explain their menu, which is absolutely essential to a restaurant so new.

[Tonkotsu Ramen] - A-.
So, without adding any toppings, it comes with chashu, cabbage, half a soft-boiled egg, some wooden mushroom, and of course ramen. I added black garlic, extra pork belly, extra cabbage, with mild spicy level.

First, the broth. Is it authentic? No. Special? No. But clearly the chef knows what he/she's doing. The thing I liked about it was that it's considered pretty rich in texture, but it was not very salty at all. I guess they did't really put MSG in it which is certainly a plus. I can't eat too spicy so mild spicy was just about right for me. Black garlic did enhance the taste of the broth.

Ramen wasn't the best I have tried but it was not bad. If anything, I would be expecting thicker noodle and a bit harder texture i.e. less cooking time. For the egg, I wouldn't call that soft-boiled at all - it was 90% cooked. Maybe it was cut in half and heat could get into the egg easily?

But man, the best part was the meat. Pork Belly was bomb! I think I haven't had such good pork belly for a long while - super tender, fat portion was about 1/3 of the whole piece which to me was just about right; and the taste was super, super phenomenal. I should really have ordered quadruple pork belly. Chashu on the other hand was way above average too. It was very moist and thinly cut. Too bad I had it with pork belly and the chashu couldn't be compared at the same level.

The addition of cabbage was a nice touch to the ramen as a whole. I think it definitely served the purpose of neutralizing the broth, whether it's good or bad depends on people, but cabbage + rich tonkotsu broth was another thing I found quite unique about.

The ramen itself, without adding anything, costs $11.50. But I ended up paying $18+tax with adding all those ingredients. Definitely on the expensive side. One may wonder whether its worth paying such a price for an unauthentic Japanese ramen shop? It's a hard question, because I can really get an Orenchi with a beer with this price. But the pork belly really set this place apart. I will definitely come back to try their Miso Ramen next time!
author: Simon C.

description:
Three things I love about winter:

(1) Hibernating in bed.
(2) Getting facials...from a steaming bowl of noodles or from ayce shabu/hot pot.
(3) Cold weather clothing that covers up pudgy pudges from hibernating in bed after gorging a huge steaming bowl of noodles or from ayce shabu/hot pot. 

Ok, who am I kidding. I have pudgy pudges all year round and multiple layers of clothing makes me look like the the Michelin Man. *le sigh*

It's ramen weather now so I've been on a hunt for a good bowl of ramen without msg. Admittedly, I was very skeptical about Coco's Ramen. It's from the same owners as Crazy Sushi and it's not Japanese owned or operated. I thought it would be another run-of-the-mill, Chinese owned ramen joint. 

Well, I was wrong....

Opening on November 12th, Coco's Ramen serves 7 ramen varieties among typical Japanese apps (agedashi tofu, karaage, and gyoza), and yakitori. Ramen menu: http://bit.ly/1r14bH2. Sake, shochu, and beer is available (I had the sugar-free iichiko on the rocks and it gave me a good buzz). They use no msg in any of their food. Woot woot!

We started with House Fried Chicken Wings ($7) and the Gyutan: Beef Tongue Yakitori ($5). The chicken wings weren't exactly what I expected them to be but they were darn good: http://bit.ly/1zGu1FC. The drummettes were marinated, partially deboned, battered and fried. They were crunchy, flavorful, and moist. I found it odd that they served it with Thai sweet chili dipping sauce though. I would skip the yakitori. The gyutan was dinky, very thinly sliced, and overseasoned with shio (salt) and black pepper: http://bit.ly/1F7dQEe. Yakitori typically isn't seasoned with black pepper. We were given Teba: Chicken Wings by accident. 

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen ($11.50) which comes with nori, half a soft-boiled egg, your choice of chashu (pork shoulder) or pork belly, and your specified level of spiciness: http://bit.ly/1AnvRhT. I asked for both protein options (+$3) and no spicy (I like to doctor up the broth myself with togarashi chili pepper). I also added black garlic (+$1) and corn (no add'l charge). 

I was pleasantly surprised with how good the ramen was for Bernal Heights. I think they accidentally added spice because my tonkotsu broth had a red hue but that was fine. The broth was rich and subtly creamy. It's not as creamy as other tonkotsu broths because they use a combo of pork and chicken stock. Seasoning wise, it was flavorful to me but people who favor msg-laden broths may find it a little bland. The thick, curly noodles seemed very commercialized but they were perfectly cooked; al-dente with a nice, toothsome chew. Definitely opt for the tender chashu over the pork belly which was dry. The highlight? The soft-boiled egg. I hate when ramen joint overcook their eggs. Here, the yolk was still custardy with a slightly molten core: http://bit.ly/1xGwsKp. Pure deliciousness. 

Service was very pleasant and the staff was really nice. They checked up on us several times. However, they seem to having issues in the kitchen because it took 30 minutes for our bowl of ramen in an empty restaurant (one other couple there). Hopefully, they streamline their processes once they iron out their kinks. One of my gripes was they charged us for the Teba: Chicken Wings. A customer should never have to pay for something that was given to them in error. 

The ambiance is quite quirky. It's like being in my Chinese great-grandmother's living room with antique Chinese furnishings (chairs were uncomfortable) and pictures of cute South East Asian children. It's a shared space with Crazy Sushi so there's only 5 four-tops, and 8 counter seats. 

Parking in the area is pretty difficult after 6 pm (next to Pizza Hacker, half a block away from Ichi and Front Porch). 

Feedback to the Owner:
I overheard the couple next to us asking a lot of questions about the menu which can be much improved. People may not be familiar with items on the menu like geso karaage (fried squid) or tonkatsu kushiage (deep fried pork skewers) so having short descriptions/translations of what these items are will be more efficient for your staff and your customers. Also, the ramen menu is not very clear: 1) There needs to be a clear distinction that you get a choice of chashu OR pork belly;  2) If you will be charging for black garlic, that needs to be specified on the menu (looks complimentary); 3) List all toppings (corn was available but not listed on the menu). 

Lastly, making a flavorful ramen broth without msg is not an easy task. It's a great selling point for the area so you should consider adding that you don't use msg into the existing paragraph explaining how your ramen is made.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
mood: http://i740.photobucket.com/albums/xx45/TheStigIsBig/blackguyclapping.gif

Ill refrain from saying "I'm in love with the CoCo!" and instead state, arguably the best ramen I've had in San Francisco. 

Bold claim, sure, but the food was so fantastic that it warranted a review after one visit. 

It was a typical Monday. Cold, dreary and lacking sleep from an eventful birthday weekend packed with singing, dancing, drinking and sing-a-longs. After a hectic day at the office (and a vow to go on a diet), convenience overshadowed logic and resorted to yelp to find a quick bite instead of cooking. It was cold and we were dehydrated so ramen was the quick and reasonable solution. We wanted to find something in our hood, which is where Coco's was a beaming light in an otherwise dark Monday.

While sitting in traffic, I scanned the reviews and vetted our remedies; My stomach growled in excitement and anticipation.

Upon coming in, you notice it's a small joint where the restaurant is literally split in half by a curtain..... where clearly patrons favor the ramen over the sushi. The ramen side had a small wait while the sushi side was a ghost town. Maybe everyone shared our Monday blues?

Due to popular demand, we started with the Kobocha as it peaked our interest and definitely delivered. The outside was perfectly fried and topped with spicy mayo. The anticipation set in as we cut in half, where the pumpkin mash and a beautiful slow cooked eggs greeted us with open arms. The combination of flavors, textures and sauces were a fantastic beginning of what was to come. At $10, it may be a bit steep for some but definitely justified as the only way to eat it would be to share. 

I had the curry ramen, medium spicy with garlic and pork belly and it was a game changer. It kind of reminded me of a Japanese version of bun bo hue; flavorful, spicy and full of full-bodied spices. One of my favorite meals is Japanese curry chicken over rice, which was this in soup form. The pork belly was beautifully tender and melted in my mouth, had yet another slow cooked egg and the noodles were cooked to perfection.

She had the miso ramen, not spicy with garlic and, again, one of the better miso broths I've had in SF. The pork belly was cooked wonderfully and they didn't skimp out on the quantity like some other ramen spots.

While this may fall on deaf ears, coco's is the real deal. I have eaten ramen all over the world and, more specifically, all over japan and coco's is a front runner on the world stage. I foresee daydreaming of curry ramen with pork belly (ie: now) while all other ramen options get pushed to the back burner. Other ramen places charge an additional $4 for pork belly options, while cocos includes it making this an affordable tasty option as well. 

Note: while I didn't drink, they do have an array of premium sake options and Kirin on draft (most have bottled, there is a difference!). it does get crowded as tables are limited, so come early and come ready to wait. Totally worth it.
author: Ryan L.

description: The location would probably be one of the downside for this place, it's hard to find parking and it's only street parking. Aside from that, the Ramen I got was pretty good. I like my ramen spicy - so the Tonkotsu medium spicy with black garlic is a must try! I got the deep fried egg, wasn't much of a fan especially for the pricy amount it was.  The ramen noodles were firm and yummy. But the broth was rich in flavor and not too spicy. I'd probably get the spicier level next time. But overall it was really good!
author: Elaine D.

description: I don't understand why anyone would go back to this place more than once. It's been about 30 minutes since I ate one bite of the nasu dengaku (grilled eggplant with what was supposedly sweet miso sauce), and I can still taste the burnt flavor of it. I literally couldn't even swallow the bite. I also ordered the veggie ramen. The sauce was so salty that I couldn't even eat it. I asked for hot water, was given unsalted veggie broth to pour into it, but even with that it was inedible. For those of you who think, of course it's bad, the meat ones are probably better, I'd like to say that I've had some absolutely delicious veggie ramen in other places. The chef clearly put no thought or care into the food, and I won't be coming back. Also, the friend I came here with is Japanese, she didn't order anything but she'd been there before. She said this is not authentic Japanese food. Even if it were to be inauthentic, I can usually manage to eat what I order at a restaurant. This was entirely unacceptable.
author: Angela S.

description:
Kinda strange. No music. One worker in front of house, but service was still cool. 

Pork belly tastes like Chinese 5-spice seasoning (strong star anise flavor), which didn't work for me. Noodles were hella good though. If I end up back here, I'll either try the veggie ramen or go for the chashu. Overall.. not in a rush to go back.
author: Michio F.

description:
Found this place on yelp whilst searching for ramen in SF. Though the place is pretty hard to find, once you do go in and sit down, the food is worth the wait. 

Food we ordered:
-Poke Salad: had an assortment of marinated fish. Not the typical Hawaiian poke I was expecting. The marinade was not spicy at all and tasted mainly like soy sauce and sesame oil. Still pretty good flavor though. Just know that this heap of fish is fooling you! There's a mountain of cucumbers hiding under it. 

-Chicken karaage: pretty good! You can't mess up too much on fried chicken. The chicken meat was tender and moist, not dry like some places I've tried. Their sauce is pretty delicious as well. I would recommend this appetizer for sure.

-Tonkotsu Ramen: I ordered my ramen with black garlic ($1 more) and chasu, medium spicy. Overall pretty satisfied with this bowl of ramen. Good strong broth, ramen had good chewiness texture, egg was a perfect soft boil. 

Wish we ordered their kabocha egg. Too bad we were stuffed already - almost couldn't finish the ramen! Def will try this next time we come!
author: Ava F.

description: SUPER GOOD Tonkotsu ramen! It's the best in the city i've had so far. I look forward to going back.  Also the staff is very friendly.
author: Ryan S.

description:
TLDR: Tonkastu Ramen was decent but the Kobocha egg appetizer was amazing! Get there by 5:30 to avoid waiting for a table. I would come back again because of proximity to my apt.

THE FOOD
Kobocha (basically the Japanese version of a scotch egg): This was fantastic!!!! The pumpkin mash was smooth and flavorful with a perfectly deep fried crunchy outer layer, and the slow cooked tea egg inside was just heaven on earth. A little steep at $12 a pop but totally worth it!!!!

Seaweed salad: standard. I like that it was seasoned properly.

Eggplant appetizer: I wish the eggplant was marinaded in the sauces more. My friends liked the charred smoky taste, but I thought it was just ok.

Tonkatsu Ramen: Broth is on the creamy side, which I prefer, but nothing mind blowing. I liked that the noodles are el dente. I preferred the pork belly over the chasu, but for those who don't like fatty meats, stick to the chasu.

WAS THERE A WAIT?
They don't' take reservations here so to avoid waiting, come when it opens at 5:30pm. I came on a Sunday night and got seated right away. I noticed a small line starting to form by around 6:15. I'm guessing it's a 15-25 minute wait if you come around prime time.

ATMOSPHERE
Simple, warm, and cozy. The place probably seats around 30 people so it's not a huge restaurant. I also noticed that it's connected to the sushi restaurant next door. Pretty certain they share a kitchen.

SERVICE
The right amount of attentive. The appetizers came out almost immediately. The ramen took about 15-20 minutes but could be because we were the first ones seated.
author: Catherine C.

description: Only had the fried house chicken wings cause I was sick and guess what IT MADE ME SICKER!  my fault though but they weren't that good.. And the service was superrrr slowwwwwwwww!
author: Shirley G.

description:
What I got:
Tonkatsu ramen w/ pork belly

What I thought:
The ramen here is honestly probably one of the best I've had in the city. 

First off, I love that they use the thicker noodles for their ramen. Makes it taste that much better, in my opinion. The broth was extremely flavorful. I added in their black garlic which is an aged garlic sauce and it added in an extra delicious punch. The pork belly was gold! Very tender and just melted in my mouth.

Couldn't get enough and kind of wish I had more now that I'm writing this review! A+ for sure!
author: Tony V.

description:
WHY WE WENT HERE:
- recovery meal post-rave
- soup is usually our go-to when recovering from a night of partying

THE LOOK (FROM THE OUTSIDE):
- easy to miss; on a busy street and you have to go into the establishment that has "SUSHI" by the window
- street parking; might be a walk once you find parking

THE LOOK (FROM THE INSIDE):
- hole in the wall
- quaint/intimate feel

THE MENU:
- appetizers: special dishes, fried, yakitori, vegetable)
- ramen

WHAT WE ORDERED:
- hot tea
- chicken karaage
- we all ordered different variations of the tonkotsu ramen (garlic, black garlic, mild spiciness, medium spiciness, braised pork belly, chashu)

THE TASTE:
- very good
- very fresh

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
- fast
- polite
- attentive
author: Sarah-Lorraine L.

description:
Coco Ramen is a great underrated spot for the Mission when it comes to Ramen, here are the two items that I've tried on the menu:

Curry Ramen (top), Tonkotsu Ramen Bottom: (https://www.instagram.com/p/BAnYTHynh9E/?taken-by=foodoofus)

The Tonkotsu Ramen, has all the trimmings of a savory and hearty ramen. The broth is deep and unctuous, there's many thin slices stewing in the bowl, the boiled eggs gave off the idea that everything was brûlée'd. The nori, was a bit of excess for the salt factor seeing as the ramen was already heavy and dense. The pieces of pickled ginger, helped alleviated with the umami factor however I wish there was a hint of citrus to cut through it all.

The Curry Ramen, was the more balanced of the two ramen. All of the flavors packed in reminded me of Curry Rice (if you haven't had it, you need to try it sometime). The deep under tones of Beef Gravy, Pepper, and Chili Powder came into effect. The scallions didn't really do much but add a tiny hill of green on the lake of curry. The only improvement I would make on this dish is to add beef slices instead of pork (the pork was tasty but didn't really do it for me).

Getting here is a bit of a pain and street parking is very scarce, so be on the look out for Paid Parking lots to help alleviate your stress.

My overall score is a four, the cost, the flavors, and the ambiance were nice. However it's a bit of a trek just to try this place, so I'm still on the fence (3.5 in actuality but I'll round to a 4).
author: Ryan M.

description: As of right now this is my favorite ramen spot in the city. I usually get Tonkatsu with either chicken karage or pork chasu(both are excellent). The broth is very flavorful and not too salty which tends to be a problem whenever I try new spots in the city. The curry ramen is pretty good as well. Broth is thicker and the flavor is bold and like their tonkatsu isn't too salty.
author: Alvin D.

description: Coco does not serve traditional ramen by any means.  Too heavy on the clove, star-anise, and white pepper in the broth.  Ended up tasting more like Taiwanese beef noodle stew than a proper tonkatsu.  Both broths were incredibly over-seasoned and left us parched for hours after the meal.  The noodles were cooked past al-dente resulting in soft textureless consistently without any of the springiness present in traditional Kyoto ramen.  There was also a very heavy layer of congealed pork fat over the broth which was not very appetizing.  I'm not quite sure how this place has the rating it has today, but I realize SF just doesn't have many proper ramen joints.  Also, it was pretty expensive granted it wasn't really authentic by any means.
author: David C.

description:
I must admit, I expected a lot. With that said. I was sorely disappointed with my meal.

I ordered a spicy tonkastu ramen with garlic and chashu, while he ordered a spicy seafood ramen with garlic. The chashu was not bad, had great flavor. However, the noodles were too firm for my liking and the broth tasted bland. I really enjoyed my bf's seafood broth, though. Additionally, he only got one shrimp and one mussel in his soup, which I felt kind of sucked for him since I got two slabs of meat. 

Overall, just OK for me. Not worth the hype, price, and trip to Bernal.
author: Leslie C.

description:
Pros: Nice atmosphere, and great location. Reasonable price and a variety of Ramen. Tonkatsu Ramen is good. Do not order it medium spicy.  It's to hot and the spicy sauce ruins the flavor. The Goyza were ok; however the dipping sauce was not good.  I would come again and try the soup with mild heat.

Cons: I ordered the pork belly skewers which were tough. I would not order them again
author: Francisca C.

description: Spicy miso ramen with pork belly was amazing *;) the pork belly just falls off your chopsticks and is packed with flavour. My boyfriend had the tonkatsu ramen and the soup was creamy and rich. The sake is on the expensive side ($20) but the type we got was super smooth with hints of grape and rice.
author: Carol P.

description:
Went to San Francisco this summer and wanted to eat some ramen. After searching yelp, Coco's Ramen was one the few places with 4 or more stars. It did not disappoint. The place is very nice and quaint. It's small but I think it adds to the ambiance. I did have trouble finding the place as the sign on the outside has a different name. Apparently, it shares the space with a sushi place. I don't know if this is still the case. 

They have several ramen broth flavors. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and added sweet corn. The broth was so flavorful. There was plenty of pork belly. The soft boiled egg was boiled to perfection. The noodles were cooked al dente. In conclusion,  Coco's ramen lived up to the expectations. I wished I lived in San Francisco so I could eat here any time I want.
author: Rintaro A.

description:
I hate to say it but wow this place is awesome.

Ramen is Japanese style (e.g. noodles are a little al dente).

My new favorite is a mild, Tonkotsu with garlic with pork belly.

Tonkotsu comes with the egg, bamboo shoots, black mushrooms (came also with red ginger, not my thing)

Shio comes with the egg, bamboo shoots, and wakame (seaweed) like things.  Way too seafoody for me in a Shio bowl.  And I missed the mushrooms.

I tried the black garlic on a medium spicy Shio also, but I'm not sure I really liked that. I think the Shio lacks the richness of the Tonkotsu.  

Mochi ice cream is not worth it - $6 for 2 mochi ice cream that they cut in pieces and add whipped cream and chocolate.  You're better off going to Trader Joe's after and buying the whole box for that.

Chashu is not the most flavorful or tender (and a little fatty).  Pork belly is super flavorful but as expected very fatty.  Don't scream at me, but I don't like the fat so I just cut the meat around it and it was super tasty.

The spice levels are either 1-10 or no spice, mild, medium, spicy, very spicy I think.  Depends on who your server is.  If you get NO spice, it comes pretty bland, but if you get MILD spice, it comes almost medium spice - I think it's some spice with chili oil or something so it sort of goes from 0 to spice just by adding it.  If you want the clean straight taste of tonkotsu get NO spice.

Reservations for large parties only (6 I think?).  Gets crowded for dinner.  Super empty for lunch. Not the most space to wait inside so you might have to wait on the sidewalk or squeeze. 

Street parking is fairly easy over on Valencia with a short walk around the corner.

Shares space with a sushi place that was empty; bathroom is over on the sushi place.  They might be willing to seat you there if they can at least.

Super casual

Takes major credit cards.

CLOSED TUESDAY.
author: Traci H.

description:
Great experience here at coco ramen. 

The noodles are firm and curly, giving great texture. 

The broth, rich and full of flavor, leaving our taste buds wanting more after each bite. 

The pork belly basically melted in my mouth. 

They had different levels of spiciness, which I appreciated a lot. I chose the mild option, and it still gave a little kick, but I was fairly warned by the waiter. 

The ambiance is very warm and cozy. A small shop that gives off a a very friendly vibe. 

Will definitely return.
author: Benjamin A.

description:
Rare that Yelp leads me astray, but sadly one o' those times.

I got the tonkatsu at medium spicy. Everything about the ramen struck me as Chinese rather than Japanese, not that that's enough to ding the place. The main thing was that the broth tastes exactly like INSTANT ramen (Shin Ramyun to be exact). It's hard to tell what went into making the broth when even medium spice overwhelms all other flavors (I suspect a heavy hand with the MSG). 

The pork belly was actually decently cooked, nice flavors, but the egg that comes with the ramen is pretty awful. Not only do you get just half an egg, but mine came at the bottom of the bowl with most of the yolk floating away. No taste really beyond being the Chinese tea egg style. The presentation also was somewhat lacking, with random red threads floating atop.

Menu is also somewhat confusing, and I wouldn't have realized that an egg comes with each bowl if other Yelpers hadn't mentioned it. It's also left unclear whether garlic is something they charge for, or whether it's just black garlic. 

If you've had ramen anywhere else, you won't be impressed either.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I think this is my favorite ramen place in SF!! I came here on a Friday night with 3 of my girlfriends at 7pm. The restaurant is pretty small so we had to wait for a table. When we finally sat down, they gave us 2 wine bottles of water (thought it was free alcohol.... Noooope haha) and menus. 

I ended up ordering the tonkotsu ramen with pork belly, mild spicy, with garlic ($11.50). I love that they give you the option to choose between pork belly and chasu here!! And also the option to add black garlic, but I wasn't feelin a $1 increase after seeing the prices here. An order of ramen comes with a soft boiled egg, a piece of seaweed, bamboo shoots, green onions, and your choice of meat. The bowls came out a couple minutes later and they looked so good!! We all dug in and were so impressed--you can definitely taste the pork/chicken combination broth here and it is delicious! Not too salty, no MSG, and light enough to the point where it doesn't get too rich. You can also really taste the garlic here!! Makes me wonder about the black garlic.. Mmmmm! Be careful with the mild spicy though, usually I'm okay with mild but this was definitely higher on the spice level for me. Kind of like a medium, so I'll probably get no spice next time. The noodles were cooked perfectly al dente. The soft boiled egg was one of the better ones I've had at ramen places. I hate ordering a soft boiled egg and when I get it, it's room temp/cold, but here it was warm and the egg yolk was runny. The star of the bowl was definitely the pork belly though!! I've never seen a ramen place offer pork belly instead of chasu so I thought it was pretty generous/cool of them haha. They gave 3 thick pieces and it was more than enough for me. It was soft, tender, and definitely melted in my mouth!! I usually hate fat on meat but I don't mind it on pork belly... Makes it so good!

Service was okay. We literally only saw our waiter like 3 times, and it's a small place!! Probably because they gave us the water already. 

Only gripe about this place is that it's a bit pricey... Paying close to $12 for a bowl of ramen? And corn is $2 more!!!! :( Also I didn't finish my noodles, but I can see how it's a smaller portion than other places. Still, I am giving Coco's ramen 5 stars because of that pork belly and the broth!!!
author: Tara A.

description:
Truly wonderful little spot on Mission and 29th. Owner's are Chinese and the Ramen shop is adjoining their Sushi restaurant. Usually not good signs, but WOW!! This place was the exception to the rule.

Ordered medium spicy Tonkatsu ramen with chashu and corn, the noodles were firm and chewy, held up well to the rich and full flavored broth. Perfect! I don't like that they charge extra for black garlic oil and veggies like corn, but the base price was SF reasonable enough, $11.50 plus $2.00 for corn. The hostess and our server were possibly like mother and son, with dad making occasional appearances, all very friendly and helpful. They obviously take pride in their clean and homey little enterprise.

The eggs were a highlight, perfectly soft and flavored, chicken drumettes were awesome with lemon squeezed over. Chashu had a little Chinese flavor, gingery, which I prefer. Meat wasn't notable, but everything else was.


Way better than anywhere in Japantown, my other Bay Area favorites are Santa in San Mateo and Ajisen in Fremont is my current top due to the delish short rib ramen. CoCo is on par and cute to boot! 

This place opened four months ago so at 7pm on a chilly Saturday there was only ever 1 group waiting to be seated at a time. I guarantee this will change soon.
author: Lily G.

description: Food is ok but bad operation. Server didn't know how much is palm wine, forgot to send the appetizer  we ordered, another  appetizer came before main dishes. There is pricing issue with the the wine,$8 per cup and $25 per bottle but looks like each bottle only serve 3 cups...
author: Anya C.

description:
Solid ramen spot on Mission. Huge portion of ramen and super cute ambience.. 

The broth wasn't as creamy as I'd like but it was definitely rich. You can taste the pork and chicken in it. Bf and I got extra noodles and I think we can pass on that the next time we come because it was too much!

The fried cheese ($4) was really good. I was actually surprised at how much I liked it.

We also ordered the Crazy Jalapeño ($7) which came late and was entirely too spicy for me.. I literally started tearing up after a few seconds.. Now I know the trick to crying if I ever pursue acting lol.

Water comes in carafes but the BF and I drink water like crazy so we had to keep requesting some hence the minus star. We waited quite a bit for the check too. They made it up though with packing up our togo for us. I am a sucker for places that pack up our leftovers. 

All in all, I'd come here again to try their other dishes with the ramen we had ordered. I'll just be sure to bring a water bottle with me next time!
author: Jayne S.

description:
People seem to rave about this place, but to me it is very average.  Truth is, there isn't any other ramen spots around here and well, ramen is tasty!  but this one doesn't blow me away or anything.

For starters, you cannot get any type for ramen for under $11.  Okay, I guess that's pretty average in SF these days.  They give you a very fair portion of food, but the ingredients never seem that fresh to me.  The brussels sprouts and cabbage have zero flavor, like they've been sitting in a freezer for a week.

The broth however, is terrific, so it kind of masks the other ingredients.  It packs a spicy punch if you want it to, and is great to just drink on it its own.

The place is usually packed, parking is almost impossible in the area, and they do not deliver (womp womp :().  So yeah, I just can't get too excited about going here.  It is kind of a neighborhood default at the moment, since it's the only ramen around.  If something better comes along I won't feel bad about about going there instead of coco's.
author: Thomas T.

description:
This is a decent place to have a yummy bowl of ramen, but I wouldn't recommend dining with a large party as it's very small and they may have trouble accommodating large groups.

I dined with my husband, and we sat in the window and enjoyed people watching (on Halloween no less) while we enjoyed our ramen.  I had the tonkotsu ramen with black garlic, sake, and a beer.  All were delicious.  The waiter wasn't overly friendly, but the goal of a restaurant like this is to have customers in and out quickly so more people can enjoy dining here, which is understandable.  Definitely a good spot if you're looking for ramen!
author: Christy C.

description:
The ramen here is good, it's up there on the ramen front. I got the veggie ramen, which does include a half and egg, as well as tofu, keep note; definitely a good choice from the menu. Oh, and don't feel have to order another egg on the side, as I did, but it was darn good...it comes cold though, so either put it in your ramen when it arrives, or have them warm it up:) 

The rest of the menu looked pretty good too, including a solid and varietal sushi menu, drinks as well as other entrees, appetizers and dessert. They have a specials menu too. 

One star off due to the fact they screwed up my ordered (all the wrong veggies), and didn't take the time to mention to me that my dish already came with an egg. But they did try to make up for the veggie issue by bringing me the veggies they missed without charging me, and gave me a full apology. 

A little out of the way of typical places in SF to get ramen, but worth the experience.
author: Sonia A.

description: A wonderful gem tucked away on the edge of San Francisco city. The ramen here was better than most of the ramen shops in San Francisco's Japan Town and the Mission. Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area.
author: Erick T.

description: I had high hopes for this place given the positive reviews on Yelp, including one that says this was the best ramen in SF. Usually don't go out for ramen since it is so easy to make at home and we are exceptional cooks. Should have stayed home. Went there on a Saturday night early. Lots of diners. Good sign. Service very strange as if the young woman has never done this before. Not a big deal. Ramen was good but very simple and did not quite taste like Japanese ramen. When ordering, waitress asked us how spicy we want the ramen. Strange question for a ramen place but understandable when the waitress told us owners are Chinese. No prejudice here since our group was mostly Chinese and Korean Americans. Ordered beef tongue and squid "yakitori" as appetizers. Both came well after our ramen was served. The grilled tongue was cold, tasteless, and was so tough it was almost inedible! I think they sliced the tongue raw than grilled it with no seasoning. Tongue needs to be cooked for a long time before you grill it. I don't think they knew that. The squid was huge, tasteless, and very chewy, and they served it with a Thousand Island like sauce. Not to say Chinese chefs  can't make Japanese food (most Japanese restaurants in SF are owned by Koreans and on the whole they are very good) but on this night, the food was simply not acceptable, especially in a foodie town like SF.
author: Hanuman C.

description:
I've been patiently waiting for an authentic ramen joint to arrive in the Bernal area and this place is one of my new favorites in the entire city!! When you walk in, the decor is very cute and traditional, with wood cladding, antique chairs, and paintings of sake along the wall. 

But onto the ramen... I enjoy how they offer many variations in their menu including lighter chasu versus the fattier pork belly. As far as the soup bases go, I have tried the tonkatsu, miso, and shio, and prefer the more refreshing shio with black garlic and medium spiciness. They give you half a soft boiled egg which is cooked perfectly every time I've eaten here, and the noodles are always cooked to perfection and never soft or overdone. I'm actually hoping people keep this place kind of an undiscovered secret because I prefer it a lot over the more hyped and crowded ramen shops that have been opening up all over the city these days.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Pretty good Ramen, good chewy noodles, flavorful soup, good levels of spicy to choose from, I got medium and it was spicy enough for me.

Had some of the skewers, a little too salty for my taste. Would return for ramen.
author: Sherman H.

description:
Very solid ramen spot. Service was good (friendly and quick) and the price is very reasonable. The place can get crowded occasionally, but usually only for dinner (which is why I prefer coming for lunch).

In terms of the food itself, I always get the tonkatsu ramen. The broth is very rich and the noodles are a good texture. I haven't gotten too many other dishes just because the tonkatsu ramen is very solid.

I come here maybe once a month and have had a good experience every time.
author: Mark Y.

description:
This place is sooooooo goood. The 1st couple times I visited, I hesitated about telling you about this place bc I wanted to be able to continue to waltz in on a fri or sat night and not have to wait. Well, it seems the word is out already as the last time I visited was a Fri night and I had to wait about 15-20 mins. 

Tip: look for the giant sign that says "crazy sushi" and then walk in the door on the left with a paper sign on the door that says "ramen". 

Food: excellent. All the broths are great. I highly recommend getting black garlic with your soup. It adds a nice layered depth of flavor - very similar to roasted garlic. 
Also, the Kabocha appetizer is truly excellent as others have pointed out. 

Con: the last time we went (and it was the busiest of all the times we visited) the broth wasn't as deep and flavorful as it was on our  previous visits. I hope they are able to maintain the quality as they scale up. 

Keep in mind: It is small both in space and menu selection.  That's bc they are trying to do one thing really well.  It's common practice in Japan to have a small restaurant focused on Ramen. Better to do one thing well than do several things at an average level! 

Anyways, we really enjoyed the food here! Hope to get in a few more visits before the secret is fully out!
author: Alison H.

description: Pretty good ramen but didn't have many other options besides pork
author: Navdeep D.

description: Best ramen that I've had in San Francisco! I like the curry ramen best.
author: Cate L.

description:
My first really good bowl of ramen since I've been living in San Francisco.  Although I little bit of a drive from my apartment, the reviews were enough to get me out to Bernal Heights.  Coco's is a tiny place with maybe 8 tables total.  Luckily I didn't have to wait long for a seat.  

Examining the menu, there are several broth options to choose from: seafood, tonkotsu, miso, shoyu, shio, veggie and curry. Coco's is one of the few places I've seen that offers a braised pork belly option, in addition to the standard char siu pork.  I personally think that the measure of a great ramen shop is the quality of their tonkotsu broth.  I ordered it spicy (short of very spicy), double egg and double pork belly.  Oh yeah, I went large on this one. 

My steaming hot bowl of noodles and broth arrived within 10 minutes.  My first sip of broth revealed a nice richness, without being heavy, and a significant kick of spice.  Makes me wonder how potent the "very spicy" option would have been.  Overall, a very nice first impression.  The braised pork belly was nice and tender, but had an odd sweetness I didn't expect.  At first, it was a bit unusual.  But as the spiciness continued to build, the sweet pork offered a nice counterpoint.  But the real star of the show here might have been the soft boiled egg, which was perfectly done yolky unctiousness.   

Service is friendly and fairly attentive.  Decor is what you would expect from a small ramen shop.  Don't come here for how the place looks.

Good stuff!  I'm sure to be back again.
author: Bryce B.

description: All I can say is, wow! This place makes one of the best tonkatsu ramen that I've ever had! The pork belly is nicely cooked, so well that it melts in your mouth.. Not to mention the black garlic to top it off. It's a must try. One tip though, don't go during prime time and avoid going with a large group..
author: Rochell S.

description:
Hubby & I came here on a Saturday night at around 7:30, the place was packed but fortunately we didn't have to wait long. We tried to order some oysters but they were out of it, so we picked the garlic flowers but they were out of them too, so we had the bacon wrapped mochi only as appetizers. 

The appetizer was surprisingly delicious! the flavors of the seasoning with bacon and mochi was just perfect. Then we each had the Tonkotsu ramen. It took a while for the ramen to arrive, but when it did it was boiling hot. We had to stir it around to cool it a little. The broth was good, rich and garlic-y (because I added the garlic but my hubby added the black garlic which tasted better). The noodles were actually very good , al dente, chewy and a little hard in a perfect way. The Chashu was good but the pork belly was better in our opinion. 

Overall I liked Coco's Ramen it's definitely better than the average ramen, but I would give it a 3.5 stars rating if I could, because there's better ramen and the service is very slow.
author: Tamara S.

description:
This is a small place with 6 tables and some bar seats so if you're waiting for a table, you might have to wait outside and it gets chilly!! Bring a jacket.

I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen with pork belly (other option is chashu). You can choose regular garlic or black garlic (additional $1). Silly me, I didn't fully read the menu to know that it already comes with half an egg so I added another full one for $2. It was delicious so I'm not complaining. You get to choose your level of spiciness and medium was just right.

They have some appetizers and yakitori (skewers) also which is ideal for groups. The chicken wings was OK... can do without.

Staff were attentive and friendly.

I believe they share a bathroom with the sushi restaurant next door?
author: Nancy N.

description: I found the fish soup really good even though the service was horrible. They are rude and careless I am not sure if is because they don't speak English well.
author: Kira B.

description:
hhhmmmmm, the ramen here is okay. 

It felt like something was missing in the soup. For the tonkotsu ramen, which i had, it didn't have the richness of tonkotsu broth, and the flavors wasn't together. The noodle is fine, texture is there, enough amount in the bowl, it's just, it made me feel and think I had better. It wasn't special.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: What a hidden gem! This small, unassuming restaurant makes delicious Tonkotsu Ramen, tasty enough to rival the shops in Japan Town. The soft egg and fatty pork belly sat blissfully on top of perfectly aldente ramen (with just the right amount of bounce)! The broth brought all the ingredients together and was deep and flavorful. You can also tailor the broth to any spice level too (I recommend medium). Needless to say, this was a yummy lunch and I ate the ramen so fast, I forgot to take my food pic! Not a bad problem to have if you ask me!
author: Chase B.

description:
The ramen here is different from other places in SF.. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen, mild spiciness, and it came out with a red broth. The tonkatsu broth wasn't as rich as I expected. The noodles were not house made and had a little plasticky texture. The food was OK, but I think there other better places for authentic ramen in SF, such as Orenchi Beyond and Kirimachi.

The other limitation is the service. There was only one waiter/server/cashier for the entire restaurant during lunch. When the crowds came in, she was overwhelmed and the help from the kitchen had to come in.
author: Reza H.

description:
I just recently got back from Japan and while I'm not some self-proclaimed expert on ramen, I do believe this is the best joint I've been to thus far in the Bay Area that didn't charge arm and a leg. What makes it tasty?  Noodles, seasoning, meats, and the extras you can add on.

I had seaweed salad, chicken karaage, gyoza, and miso ramen with chashu with boiled egg medium spicy. Their spice levels can get intense so if you want to enjoy your food, stick to medium or something less spicy.
author: Marfel L.

description:
I really hate it when people say it's the best ramen without clarifying WHY. 

Here's my lowdown on the Tonkatsu: 

The noodles good they're the type that curls a bit that has that stronger wheaty flavor that some people love. I prefer thinner noodles so don't take me as the best judge. 
The broth has flavor without being super fatty. If you prefer the richer broth this won't be a great fit for you. I enjoyed it because I hate that overly fatty/garlicy ramen at other restaurants. 
The Chashu was nice
The Egg was that nice half-cooked that makes a ramen egg so good.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Best ramen I have had in SF! I ordered the veggie, which comes in a miso - I had the tofu/black garlic/corn combo and my husband had the pork belly and LOVED it.

Service was perfect and everyone seemed happy!
author: Brittany L.

description: Wednesday nite dining and waited no more than 5 minutes for seating for 2.  Shoyu Ramen was delicious, soft boiled egg and spicy medium was done just right. Service, too was great!  Overall, this is a solid Ramen joint. I've had better Ramen and that's the only reason why it's not 5 stars.
author: Betty Y.

description: Worth the wait. Excellent ramen. It's usually a bit crowded in the restaurant, but that's a good thing!
author: Mimi J.

description: Amazing qual - hands down best fried egg I've had in a while. I fuck with this spot heavy af
author: Amiel G.

description:
I have no idea why this place has 4 stars....it definitely is not an authentic ramen place. The best way for me to describe their ramen broth is salty, and their Chasu pork was very very dry and chewy. Aside from the food, their service was less than mediocre. We waited for 30 minutes, and requested for a table, but was forced to sit at the bar because the table was "specifically" for parties of 3 or more :( Shortly after, the party of two who had arrived after us, got to sit at the table..

What I DO recommend at this place is their Kobachas (boiled egg and mashed pumpkin deep fried)..super tasty and unique. 

All in all, i will not be going back.
author: Tracey K.

description:
More like 3.5
Gone here almost 8 times now. One of the better ramen houses of SF no doubt. (rightfully priced)
Their noodles are great. Their broth has changed over time I think - in that it feels like they're taking shortcuts (which warrants the 3.5). I surely hope not because this place is pretty solid on good (maybe not best) ramen. 
Oh and their Kabocha is amazing. Order it if you have stomach space.
author: Andy L.
