description: Had the veggie ramen with black garlic and non-spicy. I was thoroughly impressed. Broth was very flavorful without being overly salty. It was a bit busy since it was at lunchtime on a rainy Sunday afternoon.
author: Amy S.

description:
Waited 50min for our APPETIZER to come. Midway thru the wait we were told one of our ramen broths wasn't ready then a min after one of the appetizers wasn't available. 55min for our ramen to be served. NO GO.

UPDATE. Got charged for the appetizer that was sold out.
author: Christian A.

description:
Finally a good ramen place in the city! I'm sad that it's not closer to the fidi plus the area is a bit sketch, but if you are looking for a decent ramen join in the city, I would recommend coming here. This place opened not too long ago and it's still a hidden gem, so go before the line starts growing! 

I ordered their Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen w/ pork belly and black garlic ($11.50 + $1 for black garlic). The ramen noodles are the standard size, not thick like dojo and not thin like santouka, and were cooked to perfect al dente. The soup was very rich, flavorful, and hot! I was pleasantly impressed after trying out so many mediocre sf ramen joints with just warm soup. Also, their "spicy" level definitely lived up to being spicy, but not too much that you'll be burning your tongue, great for a spice addict like me. The slow-cooked egg was very very good! Finally a place that does the egg right in the city! It had a good soya flavor and the yolk was perfect (see picture). The egg was not cold either like some of the other places I've tried. Yay! The braised pork belly slices tasted a bit taiwanese, good flavor, but I thought they were a bit tough to chew. I liked how they also don't skimp on the portion! So many pieces of pork belly and enough noodles to fill your hungry self up. I must point out that their ramen had a special aroma, a bit different than the standard tonkotsu ramen I've had before. Maybe it was the spice? the black garlic? I don't know, but it didn't stop me from enjoying the nice bowl of ramen. 

TL:DR - Price is good, service is good, and most importantly the ramen is delicious. I will be returning!
author: Hoyan L.

description: Not the best ramen place- trust me and go somewhere else.
author: Tina L.

description:
Stopped by around 5:30pm on a Monday for an early dinner with a friend. We both love ramen so we were excited about all their options! The waitress was very accommodating despite all our questions about the menu. (They have a veggie ramen on the menu which is a plus!)

I got the Tonkotsu Ramen with chasu by recommendation and it was great! Nice thick broth and well-cooked noodles. They were able to give us extra garlic and green onions on the side too!
We also ordered the deep fried soft boiled egg, which they had actually forgotten about, but did bring to us eventually. It was okay, a simple fried soft-boiled egg. I wish it was warmer in the center (was a little cold) but didn't bother me much.

Overall, good random find for me and my friend!
author: Angela C.

description: Early Sunday dinner, we split a salad, grilled eggplant, kabocha squash, and a shoyu ramen with chashu.  The salad was fine, just greens with house dressing and sesame seeds.  The eggplant was not great, Italian globe eggplant instead of Japanese, so a bit watery, but a generous portion.  The kabocha was... Holy smokes what is that?!? It was a delicious soft boiled egg covered in kabocha squash with a crispy outside crust.  Kind of like a Rebel Within, but warm and smokey and savory and sweet.  Huge and delicious.  Ramen noodles were nice and bouncy, broth pretty good.  All in all a solid addition to the neighborhood.
author: Nicole B.

description: Coco's has some tasty ramen! It's not the best I've ever had but it's far from the worst! I'm always happy and full after eating here. I always order the veggie ramen. I like that they let you pick the vegetables you want in it, the level of spiciness, and whether you'd like black garlic, regular, or none. As a garlic lover, that's golden! I highly recommend them for take out if you live/work in the area but must say they are a little slow for dine in during lunch or if you have any additional requests when you come to pick up your take out during that time. With a little more organization and attentiveness, they could be 5 stars.
author: Shav S.

description: Can't find a better ramen than Coco's in San Francisco! Good verity but the Tonkatsu with pork belly is unreal!
author: Ian G.

description:
*Long Overdue! 

My fiancé and I were craving ramen one evening and stumbled on Coco's. Descent size hole in the wall with great potential in the modern traditional Japanese style atmosphere. 

*TONKATSU Ramen with chashu pork, garlic and medium spiciness: Flavorful! The broth was medium bodied, with a nice sweet and savory taste, with notes of garlic. The pork was tender and mildly sweet, very tasty! And the heat was true to choice, that togarashi on the table was no needed :). 

*Staff/service: pleasant and accommodating! 

Overall, we had a great experience! Will definitely be stopping by when that next craving hits.
author: Brittany B.

description:
Excellent Ramen!  Many choices to choose from, so good for bigger parties.  The Braised Pork Belly is very flavorful!  (better than chashu).  Pork Broth is just right!  (I cannot have extremely oily broth).  Egg is very tasty!  Portion wise is good, not gynormous but better than a number of other ramen places.  I would not judge on spiciness since this category is too subjective (all depends on where you come from...)

Service is polite, but I think they seem to have lost a couple servers recently so service might sometimes be a bit slow...  

I guess I can cut them some slack...

Since a yummy comforting bowl of ramen is always worth the wait!  (Shorter line and better taste than Santa Ramen... at least for me...  So no complains here.)

Oh, and I asked the owner, they do not add MSG.  

Anyways, definately one of my favorite ramen places in the Bay Area!
(Been to about a dozen)
author: D Y.

description: I wasn't super impressed with the Ramen. Not a lot of goodies in the broth, but the broth was nice. I've had better, but it wasn't bad. We ordered salmon kama too, an it was amazing. For those hoping to get sushi here, should know that the sushi place connected to ramen place directly is only open for dinner during lunch.
author: Marta M.

description:
Ramen is good, but probably wouldn't go out of my way to eat here. A few stars knocked off due to slow service and preventable wait time. 

Came on a Monday night around 7:30 with the SO. Wait time = easily 30-40 min. with only 3 small parties ahead of us. Why? Because this place is not only small, but the seating layout is SUPER INEFFECTIVE. Aside from a few spots at the bar, they have 5 large tables that seat parties of 4-6. Everyone waiting to be seated that night (and I imagine on most nights) were groups of 2-3. My SO and I were eventually seated at a table for 6 and ate our dinner while 3 other couples waiting to be seated had to watch us eat with 4 empty chairs next to us. Same deal at the next table over - another couple with 4 empty seats. With their small space, they should really replace their large tables with small single tables and just push them together as needed when larger groups come. Poor business decision imo. Wait time could have easily been cut down to 10-15min. 

Service: On the slower side - 25 min for 2 bowls of ramen. Waiter was nice, but when asked what appetizer he recommended, he told us he "honestly didn't know because all he's had on the menu were the chicken wings." Lolol...

Food: 
+ Kobacha (4/5): yummy, rich, and filling! Recommend sharing among 2-3 people.
- Miso Ramen (3/5): broth lacks flavor imo; skip this & get Tonkotsu ramen (4/5) instead. Noodles and pork belly were both solid. I like that you have the option of adding garlic and choosing your spice. Medium spice was more like mild - I'd up the spice lvl next time.
author: J C.

description:
My mom is always scared to go near the Mission, but anything for food right?

Coco ramen is Chinese owned, with that said, the inside of the restaurant reminds me of my grandma's house aiyaaa. You'll know what I mean when you see it.

-Tonkotsu Ramen: got mine with black garlic and chashu, no spicy. 
Noodles: mine were slightly on the soft side, a bit over cooked but nothing too bad 
Soup: slightly burnt taste to it, I couldn't tell what it was. Flavorful, but honestly could not taste the "tonkotsuness" in it
Chashu: quite dry, subtle flavor
Egg: omg amazing! Soft boiled to perfection and very tasty. 

The mother got hers with pork belly instead. It was very flavorful and very good! Just a bit chewy. However, there was a tiny cooked worm in her bowl of ramen shortly after she started eating. We told the waiter and he brought it in to the chef. We heard them arguing in Chinese lol. He told us that it was just scallion but like....we can tell the difference between a worm and green onion -___- ended up making a new bowl for my mom.

Service was decent but there was only one person working. 

Probably won't come again.
author: Jackie T.

description:
Omg! This is Taiwanese Beef Noodle! NOT RAMEN!
I don't know where ya'll eating ramen before, but this is not RAMEN! Their black garlic? Spicy pork belly? Just so so in my opinion.
However, they do give u excellent service. For that, they deserve 2 additional stars from me.
author: Icey M.

description: Came here late at night about an hour before they closed and it was still busy! It's a pretty small restaurant. There's one side specifically for sushi and another side for ramen. I had the tonkatsu ramen with black garlic. It was super rich and the noodles were the perfect al dente! I also had the thing that everyone else gets, the soft boiled egg that's like wrapped with pumpkin and deep fried. Too die for. If I lived close by I would go all the time. Unfortunately I don't. But if I'm ever in the bern heights area, I know where I'm going for ramen.
author: Jennalyn L.

description:
Coco's Ramen = Crazy Sushi.

They have a sign that says CRAZY SUSHI on the street so don't become misled. SAME PLACE. 

*Food: The Kabocha is delicious. It is an appetizer, cooked with mashed pumpkin and a mid boiled egg. The yolk is just perfect (semi cooked yolk.) I nicked name it as the "bomb". It also comes with a sweet tingly spicy mayo sauce. The sauce I say is DELICIOUS, it really exaggerates the flavor of the pumpkin. This is definitely a must try! But may I warn you, it is very filling (suggest you share with 3+ people). I also ordered the Tonkatsu Black Garlic Ramen with Chashu (meat). I cannot finish the ramen because I was so STUFFED with the Kabocha. The broth/flavor is very strong. I don't think i like it very much because it kind of covered the flavors of the noodle itself and that chashu (meat). 

Overall it was very delicious. 

*Atmosphere: the shop had 2 part rooms but when I went, only the left side is open. They have a small counter/cashier area that has a sake shelf. They have a small corner high table counter for 2 on each side. The shop is not very bright...it is dim but very soothing. There are traditional Japanese style pictures and tables/chairs.

*Service: it is a bit of a wait because it seems like there are only 2-3 workers (Mr. & Mrs. Owner & kitchen cook). Mrs. Owner keeps walking in and out of the kitchen to serve the food while Mr. Owner seems to cook more. 

So have patience.
author: Katie P.

description: Some of the best ramen I've ever had. The broth is rich. The place is nice and cozy. Service is polite and fast.
author: Arvey S.

description:
wow what a great ramen place

they have a vegan broth which is very very good

the noodles are delicious and the service is great

i really like this place and will surely be back if i'm in town again
author: Hemesh P.

description:
A little expensive, but good ramen in an up-and-coming neighborhood. Parking was a little difficult as well.
Grilled squid- not too "Squiddy"
Kara age- amazing, as usual
Ramen- pretty good, a little noodle-heavy. I shouldn't have gotten the pork belly, it didn't really add anything. 

A big plus for this place is that they have a vegetarian ramen too! Good for my sweetie who is a vegetarian.
author: Samir K.

description:
Good ramen, I got the miso ramen with medium spice. Nice hearty and creamy broth, and great large portions. Soups come with a soft boiled egg and your choice of meat, chashu or pork belly. 

A few of the downsides: horrid service. Normally I don't take this into much consideration but surprisingly this impacted my dinner here. 

Very small compact space not utilized very well. There are a few big tables for groups only, who all take their time. Not their fault, but a party of two on the waitlist took 35+ minutes with no reservations ahead. Please add tables for two that you can put together for groups, instead of two giant tables taking up the entire space. 

The space is so cramped that there's no where to sit or wait inside, even if you're the only ones waiting. 

Good ramen! Just expect a long wait, and little to no service during your wait period or when your food arrives.
author: Dominic E.

description: Decent ramen, but not incredible by any stretch of the imagination. The tonkatsu lacked flavor. They charge hefty prices for a list of add ons .  Will keep looking for my go-to ramen spot in the neighborhood
author: Lauralee O.

description: We came here for the Ramen and we're not disappointed.  I cannot say it was the best Ramen I've ever had but it was clearly in the top ranks.  For something different I tried the curry Ramen, which was really good but pretty strong so only order this if you want curry flavors rather than traditional Ramen flavors.  Others in my party had the vegetarian, tonkatsu and miso Ramen.  All were just as you'd want and really enjoyed.
author: Matt M.

description:
I'm not a ramen snob but do frequent the good spots like dojo, parlor, santoukas, and orenchi. That said the ramen here is pretty good. They aren't that fancy but do offer no/regular/black garlic options and have a good assortment of toppings. Their soft boiled egg is great! The braised pork belly is awesome too. One qualm I have is that, seeing as the owners are Chinese, there are clearly some Chinese rather than Japanese flavors, especially in the braised pork belly. It tastes like a traditional Chinese clay pot pork belly (which I love) but seemed a bit of a misfit in the ramen.

The chicken karaage likewise had a Chinese popcorn chicken taste to it.
Price was fine at $11.50 a bowl average.

Overall: 3.5 stars. Rounding down for the odd tastes, but still very delicious!
author: Charlton Y.

description: So good. 1st time trying and loved the recommendation. I got the Tonkutsu, extra spicy and was amazed. Filling as well! Def coming back.
author: Katherine R.

description: The ramen is great and so are the apps. Small venue, so be prepared to wait a bit and when it does get busy you will probably have to wait a long time to have your order taken. But definitely worth the wait if you ain't starving.
author: Pico S.

description: Super small place and it's connected to 'Crazy Sushi' so the signs outside is quite confusing. They have a good selection of small dishes and ramen. I had the spicy tonkatsu with black garlic and asked for medium, but it's not even spicy. The bowls are smaller than most ramen places but the food isn't bad. Tried the kabocha, smashed pumpkin with boiled egg in the middle, and it's quite interesting. I would love to come back and try their other ramen, but this time I'll order more spicy, and other appetizers.
author: Cindy W.

description:
3.5 but extra half since there aren't many ramen spots in the area.
The window banner only has the word "Ramen".  Initially I had trouble finding this place since I didnt know its connected to Crazy Sushi.

Tonkotsu was delightful though it wasn't as "rich" as described.  The server did not ask my garlic or spiciness preferences so guessing I got the standard non-spicy garlic broth. 
Shishito peppers were good but I would rather spend the extra $3 on add. toppings.
author: Angel W.

description:
This is the best vegetarian Ramen I have had in San Francisco. 

Ramen: The broth is pretty flavorful, and you get to choose three vegetables to add to it (out of I believe bamboo, corn, cabbage, and beansprouts).  

Protip: If you like anything moderately spicy, order this at FULL spiciness.  Anything else is a sad attempt to be spicy and really doesn't do anything.  

Service:  The are very accommodating and nice here, great staff!  I usually don't have to wait for lunch or dinner. 

Also, the sign says Crazy Sushi because they are connected restaurants.
author: Christina L.

description:
Close to my house which is a big plus. Smaller space than what I expected. I ordered the chicken katsu and chicken karaage appetizers. The Katsu was pretty good, very moist. The karaage was fried in a weird tempuraish batter, wasnt bad but it wasnt the best. I ordered Garlic, Tonkatsu Ramen with Pork belly, Spicy.  The broth could have been more spicy and garlicky, the pork was tasty. Overall, it was passable. There was only one waiter and this was during lunch so I can tell he was kind of stressed out.

Would go back again if I wanted ramen and nothing else was open around my house.
author: Dotty C.

description: This is one of my favorite Ramen spots in the city. The food is great and the service is quick once you're able to get seated. Waiting for a table can be a bit long since there isn't a lot of seating and the place is a bit small. You can even order ramen to take out and it's just as great!
author: Jorge S.

description: It saddens me to only give 2 stars as this place was in my top 5 places to eat. I've been coming here for a while and have never had any complaints. Hubby and I had a craving for ramen so we decided to stop by for dinner with our young son. It was pretty packed but that's to be expected on a Saturday night. We were seated right away and ordered our usual tonkatsu with black garlic and pork belly except when we got our order mine was missing the black garlic. Not a big deal but what happened next is why I decided to write this review. A huge group of people walk in and a few of them get seated behind us and the rest of the group is left standing as they wait for us to finish. Mind you we were still eating and the waitress comes by the table to give us our check meanwhile the group keeps glancing back at us to see how far along we are. I've never felt so uncomfortable. We got the hint and asked for to go boxes and left disappointed. I get it if they had reservations but prior to seating us could have given us a heads up that a party would be arriving soon. Sorry Cocos but we will not be returning.
author: Crystal A.

description: Outstanding!! Excellent attentive service and oishii ramen!!!  Spicy curry ramen was the show stopper.  Tonkatsu ramen was super rich and delicious.  Noodles are fantastic in texture and freshness.  Will be back to try the sushi selections.
author: Dante K.

description:
Long story short: Great Ramen in my opinion. Try it!

So this was my first time trying ramen that wasn't made by me from a package and I was not disappointed! I ordered the ramen with leaner pork and mild spiciness. It wasn't too spicy but it is hot so if you're not accustomed to spicy food, go for no spice. I added the roasted garlic and I could taste the difference when I compared it to my friends ramen which had none. It's a very small place so be prepared to wait or sit close to others eating.
author: Diego D.

description: delicious, albeit overpriced, ramen near Bernal Heights. They have Asahi Black also.
author: Long C.

description:
I've been to nearly every ramen place in San Francisco and the bay area - and there are a lot better places to go if you are looking for a solid bowl of ramen.  I ordered the tonkatsu with pork belly and black garlic oil.  Also ordered the karaage chicken.  Both were pretty mediocre for me.  The noodles were cooked well and the pork belly was solid, if unspectacular.  But the broth lacked the deep bold meaty fatty flavor that you should expect from ramen.  The spice was a bit too strong and the elements didn't work that well in the bowl.  The karaage was also mediocre.  The fried batter was sort of bland and too thick.  

I'd recommend elsewhere.
author: Warren C.

description:
By far, my favorite ramen in SF (sorry Ken Ken, you are now 2nd)! 

Pork chasu tonkatsu with hella garlic is my favorite. We took our friend from NYC and she also agreed that this was the best ramen she had ever eaten.

It's small in there, but worth the wait. It's also hard to find, because the outside still reads"Crazy Sushi". They share the space with a sushi spot next door, which doesn't get as much love as Coco's.
author: Katie D.

description: I felt like something about the soup made it taste more Chinese than a Japanese flavor ramen. I ordered the spicy Tonkatsu ramen with pork belly. The pork belly was quite fatty and a little bit on the dry side. The ramen tasted okay. The soup had a star anise-y taste to it that I was not too fond of. It reminded me of the Chinese beef tendon noodle soups at HK style cafes. I believe that this place is run by Chinese people because I heard some of the servers there talking. My bf also ordered the same thing and thought it was meh. We also ordered the miso glazed grilled egg plant and side salad. However, we got informed that the salad wasn't fresh so we ordered the beef tongue skewers. All was okay, nothing special. After our meal, I started feeling really nauseous and I had a feeling it has something to do with the ramen. I don't think I will be coming back, especially since the ramen wasn't the greatest and something tells me that their food wasn't fresh.
author: Lisa H.

description:
I'm in love with the coco. This place is the bee's knees, the cat's meow, the monkey's uncle. I got the tonkatsu with black garlic oil and my PIC got the spicy shoyu. Both were {fire emoji}. I wouldn't be surprised to see this on DJ khaled's snapchat.

This place has some major panache. Dark wood everywhere- it felt like I was in the hull of a delicious ramen boat. Take yourself here and TREAT YO SELF
author: Sam R.

description:
I like this place. I've been on a soup/Ramen kick for the last several months. I've been craving it like a junkie craves a sugar-daddy.

My office is near Bayshore and I was looking for a Ramen Place within short distance. Found this place on Yelp and decided to give it a shot.

I ordered the mild Shoyu with black garlic and a Black Asahi. Black was apparently the theme for my lunch,

Really good flavor profile. It's not a flavor combo I've ever had before. I liked it. I'm a big garlic fan, so I fear not the Garlic of death. (the wife on the other hand.......)

Oh yeah...the Black Asahi. Honestly, I was never a big fan of Japanese beer, but this thing has character. Every time I go to a Japanese place, this will be my attempted go to.

Also wasn't crowded which was great for my lunch. Place filled up after I got seated though.

The gals working there were friendly and attentive.
author: Stefano D.

description:
3.5 *s

+ wonderful server/service
+ pork belly was melt-in-your-mouth good
+chashu was delish, too
+ chicken wings tasty, but needs parchment paper underneath to soak up all the grease...
+ shishito peppers cooked so they weren't spicy, we'll done. Wish there were 4, than just 3. A $1 per pepper seems steep
+ the noodles were cooked perfectly, great texture. Egg was cooked perfect so it's gooey inside, well presented 

- the bacon mochi... ghetto. Using cheap Korean rice cakes aren't the right consistency for Japanese mochi to be eaten plainly. 
- the broth was okay, for being tonkotsu, the spice covered it up completely which I didn't mind, but it wasn't any bit creamy, which should be somewhat if its made from bones.
 But as stated on the menu, it's made with a CHICKEN broth... Therefore,  it's not a "tonkotsu" broth.... mislabeled. even Momiji has better tonkotsu broth. 

A bit pricey STARTING at $11.50. And u know u wanna add in extras like egg, corn, chashu, or pork belly... so u technically will walk out paying for a $15-$17/bowl, not including tax and tip.
I wouldn't make it my main goto ramen spot, but it's another option to have. And it's close by
author: Miss J.

description:
Finally got the chance to try this place and I was not disappointed! Definitely one of the better ramen places in San Francisco!!! The establishment is pretty small (probably seats less than 15) so it can get packed really quick.

Shared the fried calamari which was pretty good. Nicely flavored, moist, and crispy on the outside. The dipping sauce that came with it was flavorful too. Saw our neighbors order the karage as an appetizer... definitely something I will order next time around since it looked pretty good! Got the tonkatsu ramen with extra noodles. Broth is pretty thick, but it's very flavorful! I wanted to finish the broth but the heat from the soup (medium) kept making me sweat, so I had to stop... haha.  Noodles were cooked al dente, which was perfect. Nice bite to it! The half egg that came with it was cooked well, runny in the center. They're also very generous with their cha-shu portions compared to other places that give you thin cuts. My friend ordered the curry ramen, which was a soup base which literally reminded me of curry. The pork belly was good too and again, good portion size. Overall, the meal was great and I'm glad I actually live pretty close to this place. If I don't feel like treking to San Mateo for good ramen, I know that I can come here instead now! Wooohoooo!
author: Johnson S.

description:
Not a fan;/
I always try to finish everything I ordered but veggie ramen here was probably far far out from the best I have ever had and couldn't help leaving more than a half the bowl. There are not many ramen spots in my homeland Japan who serves veggie broth but hey I can tell this place does not serve authentic Japanese ramen. Rather, more like arranged Chinese noodle with ramen facade. This restaurant seems popular and I guess they must have something appealing to the locals; who knows, as this review is solely for my experience with veggie ramen.
author: K O.

description:
Went to the restaurant on a Wednesday night and was craving Ramen. The restaurant is connected to a sushi place and can be hard to find as it only has a paper sign in the window that says "Ramen".

We were seated immediately and enjoyed the music that was playing from the Sushi place, it was a lot of adult contemporary...like Adele's Hello etc. It was great background music and added to the experience. 

I'd been here before and enjoyed the Shoyu Ramen. I ordered the same Ramen this time with black garlic, chatusu, and medium spiciness. I'm recovering from a cold and the Ramen was delicious and hit the spot! The spicy was just enough I don't think I could handle the next level of spiciness. 

My friends and I also ordered the calamari appetizer and 2 bottles of saki. The calamari was really good and came with a spicy mayo dipping sauce. I highly recommend this Ramen spot, it has to the best I've been to in SF.
author: Ebonie M.

description: The vegetarian ramen is way better than any veggie ramen I've had in the city. The broth is rich and flavorful. The egg and toppings are perfectly cooked. It's a quaint place with friendly but busy staff. Worth a visit!
author: Stee R.

description:
Euggh. Came in hungover, left still hungover. I was hoping some delicious ramen would help me feel better but this was not the place to go for it. I had the tonkotsu with black garlic and pork belly, medium spice. We also got the chicken wings. Both were lame. Also the service was ridiculous.  We had to ask for chopsticks.. And then for a spoon too. 

Never again!!
author: Cat C.

description: Service was great, ladies were super nice, and the ramen was different but yummy! It was spicier than I'm used to. It came with an egg, ginger, and seaweed and your choice of chashu or pork belly, and you pick from broths ranging from Veggie to Shoyu or Tonkotsu. The bowl was quite large too. I got Tonkotsu but I would get Shoyu next time since that one is a little saltier so more flavorful. Only downside is how small the place is! Went on a weekday for dinner and we had to share a four person table with another couple. Not a big deal but would have been nice to be on our own. Overall would come back!
author: Angeline H.

description:
more like 3.5 stars

FOOD ::
+ good flavors
+ consistent quality 

SERVICE ::
- not consistent: been 3 times, first 2 times they gave me vinegar when asked and the 3rd time, the guy just said no they didn't have any (i think the first two times the other guy got it from the sushi side)
- usually understaffed, 2 out of the 3 times, there was only one server for the entire restaurant
- after delivering the food, server never checked on us again to see if everything was ok and/or if we needed anything else.  probably a byproduct of being understaffed 

MISC ::
+ we've been lucky enough to get street parking with 5-10 mins
author: Tina F.

description:
This is not ramen. The staff is all Chinese and one smell of the noodles will tell you it's a Chinese bowl of noodles not ramen. Misbranded as ramen. Also.... Extra meat and veggies are TWO DOLLARS EACH. 
After adding cabbage sprouts corn pork belly I have a 21 dollar bowl of Chinese noodles with a "ramen" label slapped on it. 
Their salad is the worst I've ever had dressing literally cheap sweet diluted yogurt and sesame. 
If you're looking for a bowl of ramen look elsewhere! You'll save yourself time money and frustration
author: Frankie C.

description: Sometimes you have to wait a bit to be seated but on a cold, foggy San Francisco day this ramen is soooo worth it. I go for the veggie ramen but the curry ramen is delicious too.
author: Mariana P.

description:
It was just a super lucky day for us when we first came to Coco's for dinner on a Friday night 2 weeks ago.  We got there at 6 pm just in time to find VIP parking right in front!  Please note that parking is hard to come by in this neighborhood.  As we entered, we got the last big table for our family of 4!  Just as we sat down, people began to pile in and formed a queue.  There was a big party sitting behind us eating and drinking for a long while so don't expect people to come in, stuff their faces, and leave right away.  There were plenty of other parties that lingered as well.  The place is not very big so just be prepared to wait if you come during dinner time.

For appetizers, we got gyoza, grilled eggplant, and house chicken wings.  The gyozas were your typical delicious pan fried dumplings.  However, the grilled eggplant was super disappointing.  It was undercooked and we were also still able to see flour-covered fingerprints on the skin of the eggplant which we initially thought was mold.  We ate two bites and left the rest on the plate which is a shame because I usually love eggplant-anything.  

We asked for the house chicken wings to be made non-spicy for my older son and they did that for us without a problem.  Even though they didn't use their usual spices to make it their "house" special, the wings were still delicious.  They carve up the wings so that it's lollipop style.  The meat is still attached to the wing but the meat is easier to eat off the bone.  My kids happily gobbled them up.

We also ordered tonkatsu ramen and curry ramen.  There was just the right amount of chewy texture to the noodles and the broth was piping hot and full of deep flavors.  However, I was not a fan of the braised pork belly in the tonkatsu base.  There was way too much going on in one bowl.  I still ate it and it definitely melted in your mouth like any good pork belly should but I felt chashu would've tasted much better with the tonkatsu base.

At the recommendation of the server, we added black garlic to the curry ramen.  I see a lot of people raving about the black garlic, however, I think we could've done without any add-on's.  We both like our ramen pretty basic so we rarely order any add-on's unless they're highly recommended.

All in all, we think this place is a great find since there are hardly any decent ramen spots in this part of town.  We'll definitely be back again!
author: Ivy Z.

description:
I'm sure I've said this before, but it's difficult to find good ramen in SF.

Coco's was a pleasant surprise. First off, the sign outside says Crazy Sushi, so don't get confused.

I had the Shio with extra chashu, and my friend had the Veggie. Noodles were great, broth was flavorful and just the right amount of spicy (I asked for medium). Pork was cooked well and hit the spot.

Service was great and attentive, and the place was fairly quiet on a Wednesday evening.
author: Brian T.

description: Not exactly what I expected. The broth is just ok. Noodles were bought and not handmade. The egg didn't melt. Meet was ok though.
author: Zhen W.

description:
dank bone based miso broth, wavy chewy alkaline noodles, and good tender menma. fair pricing. 

This is def one of the top ramen places in SF, broth of this quality in the city  is hard to find. 

the broth could be a little richer and fattier imo. they offer black garlic oil as an add on, making them legit af. 

good service, cozy decor and vibe. offers Orion beer, like I said, legit. 

The appetizers are well made, taste good, and the portions aren't too much to get thru. 

if the broth had that thick richness that they offer at orenchi or ramen shop, it'd be a 5.
author: Megan L.

description: I did a 10 miles hike before going so I was famished by the time I got there.  They didn't open exactly on time till 11:45 am by which time there were 2 others waiting.  I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen with black garlic and extra pork belly, which had tasty broth and al dente noodles.  The meat on the pork was just slightly over cooked in a couple of slices but the flavor was great.  I also ordered nasu dengaku which came out quite bland.  To be fair I've never had this before so I have nothing else to compare it to.  Will probably skip the extra pork but try their grilled items next time.
author: Becca S.

description:
Super dog UNFRIENDLY place.. they were all so scared when we walked in with my (deaf) wife's service dog. Staff felt like we brought in an Atom Bomb.
Plus if you are 2 people only, they wouldnt let you sit in a table for 4. You have to wait 30mins for someone to leave.
"0" Customer Service, now doesnt matter anymore how good their food can be!
author: tolgay k.

description: Very sub par ramen. Tasted like mediocre Chinese noodle soup (not good Chinese noodle soup). Broth just wasn't great and noodles were eh. Not sure why the reviews here are good. Maybe for the area? Missing the NYC ramen scene...
author: Linn L.

description: Great for ramen on a cold or rainy night!  Solid food, not too fancy, nice environment but small so come early to avoid waiting outside.
author: Charles T.

description:
We went to Coco's Ramen for a quick dinner last night they were closing in 40 min so we had time, we waited for s table even though a table for four was open but they said that was for 6to 7 people. There was a table attached to another table which would seat 8 comfortably and we were only two, there was a party of 7 that they insisted seat at the small table and even when we said we would take the smaller table the male employee insisted that the party of 7 sit there. Being in the restaurant business this was very poor choices in their seating arrangements.  We ordered drinks appetizers and ramen I ordered my ramen not spicy my partner ordered his mild  when I got mine it was mild spicy and my partners had no spice. We also order a beer and sake. They had to ask twice what type of sake we also ordered the raw oysters which we never received but were charged for.  When I asked they said oh so sorry it's very busy next door (crazy sushi) were they get the oysters but the funny thing was there was only a table of two people in crazy sushi so they obviously forgot the order.  
Its really sad that such a good ramen house service has to drop as they get closer to closing time.  Service should be the same when you open your doors to the time you close your doors.   Probably won't go back even though this place is less then a block away from my house.
author: B H.

description:
That was some delicious ramen. Perfect noodles, chewy and soft! The tonkotsu broth was very rich but not greasy tasting, and the soft boiled egg + garlic combined perfectly too. I had no idea this place was even here. What a nice refuge from the construction and dust on Mission!   

Accessibility: Entrance is doable in a wheelchair or scooter and much of the restaurant is on the street level, but I think the bathrooms are past a step.
author: Liz H.

description: Really good ramen and nice portion size! This place will become a regular stop for sure. I went during the weekday lunch rush and they only had one server, so it was a bit slow to be seated and then order. Not sure if that's the norm, but won't stop me from going back.
author: R S.

description: tonkotsu broth a bit dilute and noodles and cha siu ok.  not taste like some other top japanese spots.  chicken wings into drumsticks by pushing the meat down and battered and fried, cooks much faster this way, was nice.  tabasco thousand island-like dipping sauce.
author: Rob C.

description:
Good food, good service, good price.

Got the shio ramen, and it was good. I ordered mild spiciness, but was still a bit spicier than I would have preferred. However, the half egg was quite good. The ramen and pork achieved sufficient 4-yelp-star status quality, but that egg was a full 5-star item. I should have ordered another egg.

Egg. Good.

We got here around 8 pm on a Sunday, and it was decently full, but we were able to get a table on the sushi side without any wait. It was nice and quiet, so we were able to catch up and talk until 10 pm or so. Staff were very nice and never rushed us, even though they had closed.

That egg tho.
author: Allen J.

description: Never never going here again. I've never had such terrible service! From the minute we sat down the waitress/bartender was rushing us. She told us we needed to order now to put it to the kitchen before close, then fired our order mid-order so that when my date learned there were ingredients he didn't like in his dish, she wouldn't change his order!! It was nuts! Stuff like this all evening- she interrupted us mid conversation twice to ask us to pay and then sign the bill. Coco's: If you are closing, don't let new customers walk in the door. And if you're serving, don't make the customer feel like they're inconveniencing you by showing up! It's a shame because I live right down the street, but luckily there's a ramen spot right next door that has great great food and far better service.
author: Liza S.

description: This is my favorite Ramen place. I've been here about five times, and the Tonkotsu Ramen (mild) with pork belly, and black garlic is a must. There are only a few tables so the wait can be long. Also, you can hear other people's conversations. I normally come in right when it opens so I don't have to wait to get seated. Im so glad I don't have to drive to San Mateo anymore to get my ramen fix.
author: Michelle O.

description: Coco's has easily the best Ramen I've had in San Francisco. I could eat their Ramen practically every day. The broth is absolutely incredible. I don't think they make their own noodles so that's the only thing that I can say negatively about their Ramen. But their pork belly and their broth are so incredible that I can't go anywhere else for my Ramen.
author: Collen H.

description: Ramen broth full of MSG. The egg was overcooked and tasteless. I def won't be coming all the way back to eat here.
author: A W.

description:
So so so good! 
One of the better ramen places I've been to lately, I ordered the Miso Ramen with Chashu (marinated bbq pork) & my boyfriend ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with pork belly- we were BOTH very happy and full when leaving. 
It started to get crowded & busy around 6:30ish (on a Monday night mind you), we got there around 5:50/6 and it was empty.


The service wasn't that awesome after we got our food-but they did get crazy busy so it makes sense why they didn't get a chance to check in and I had to strain to make eye contact for it. 

Still, we will def be coming back since it's so close to home and not over priced!!
author: Mandy F.

description:
Yes, yes, go by the address because the sign will read, Crazy Sushi.

Pretty decent Ramen and some unique appetizers. Note you won't find the usual non-sushi Japanese restaurant items here.  

The jalapeno appetizer was not spicy at all.  The eggplant dengaku was meh.  I wouldn't order either again.

But the ramen was definitely pretty good (salty side for my tastes) and the space is definitely unique.  The pork belly was the highlight of the experience.

The table heights are awkward. The benches are much too high, so you'll probably want to use the chairs.
author: Yohdaddy M.

description: This is one of my favorite places to go for ramen. I always get in quickly, and the food is warm, hearty, and delicious. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Patty C.

description: Great place for a quick bowl of ramen. Got the tonkatsu bowl and ordered it spicy but it wasn't that hot. Also ordered the chicken yakitori. It was good but the sauce on top was too sweet.
author: Kelvin T.

description:
Solid flavorful and spicy ramen that's quite satisfying on a cold brazen night. 

Located at the cusp of Bernal Heights, Coco's is a neighborhood joint owned by the same folks from Crazy Sushi next door. The ambiance is unlike other ramen spots with actual attention showcased. It's rustic, oriental and feels very bamboo-esque. I'd venture to say Coco's makes for the perfect romantic yet casual date on a cold night.

As for the ramen itself, totally solid. The Tonkotsu ramen with pork belly and black garlic is the highlight. The pork belly itself has a sweet taste that pairs really well with the salty and rich broth. And the soft boiled egg was boiled to perfection. 

I haven't tried any of the appetizers as I went here as a second dinner but I fully intend to do so on my next trip back. 

So if you're searching for that friendly neighborhood ramen restaurant to catch up with a lady friend or have a casual date night, look no further than Coco's!

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: My favorite combination has to be the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen w/ pork belly, slow cooked egg and black garlic!
author: Marcella Renae Y.

description: Hands down the best Ramen in the city. Pork belly is sooooooo good. The staff is nice too. I love this place. I wish it wasn't so hard to get into.
author: Monica G.

description:
I should have known when I called to place my order and the phone was answered with "Crazy Sushi!" I was like oh sorry? I was trying to call Coco's Ramen..... Silence goes by and the lady comes back on the phone "ok Crazy Sushi! I take your order

I'm not sure why I trusted her but I placed my order for a curry ramen with double charsiu and pork belly, and an order of miso ramen w kimchee, slow poached egg and pork belly. To my dismay after picking up and assembling our ramen bowls I found my "kimchee" was actually bamboo shoots or completely left out, my soft poached egg was more like hard boiled and the broth for both ramen dishes were exactly the same. I think the only different was that they sprinkled a bit of curry powder in one and some miso in the other which I couldn't taste bc it was over powered by garlic.

I don't mind paying for good ramen or any food for that matter, but nearly $40 on bad ramen seems a bit much

Coco's is not making the short list next time, though I may try that Crazy Sushi joint next door
author: Audrey L.

description: Good comfort food. A bit of long line... however, you can sit next door at the sushi restaurant if you order some sushi, Coco's Ramen can bring the ramen over.
author: Caroline C.

description: Come here try. It's ok not too bad. Just like the average ramen. Good thing is price not too expensive!
author: Yueming G.

description:
One of the best ramen ive ever had. I stumbled on this place on a walk down mission. 

The tonkatsu with pork belly and black garlic. Washed it down with some cheap sake.

Simple complex great food.
author: Jon O.

description: One of my fav Ramen spots!  They have a selection of different types of Ramen broths from miso to curry which are all tasteful and delicious. And the environment is very pleasant... Def a must try :)
author: Nadya G.

description:
Coco's Ramen joins the collection of surprisingly good Japanese restaurants in the near-south-Noe area.

I had their Kobocha appetizer to start. It's Kobocha squash wrapped around a soft boiled egg and deep-fried. It's served drizzled with a sweet sauce. The egg wasn't a standout, but the deep-fried Kobocha and the sauce would be good enough for me on their own.

For an entree I had their Tonkatsu ramen with black garlic and chasu (they let you choose between pork belly or chasu and garlic or black garlic). The pork wasn't especially interesting, and neither was this soft-boiled egg. The noodles were good, and the broth was rich but not overwhelming. I got the broth "spicy" -- I would go for medium or mild in the future, as I felt that the spiciness smothered some of the other flavor in the broth.
author: Chris M.

description: Got the veggie ramen! Delicious broth and noodles. The sweet corn mixed with the medium spice was incredible. Very filling as well, I couldn't finish my bowl! The place is small, but quaint and homey. My father liked the sturdy tables despite being vey close to tables beside us. :)
author: Bea L.

description:
#1... Open for lunch!
#2... Yummy broth!
#3... Friendly staff!
#4... Good chew on the noodles!
#5... Cute cow pepper shakers!

And yes, ramen is salty.

(Yay ramen!)
author: Alex D.

description: My boyfriend and I came across this place one night on a whim a couple months ago...and we've introduced this place to our friends and have been back several times since then. This place has become my favorite ramen spot by far! Small, cute restaurant, but the food and nice staff make up for it. I've tried all their all their kinds of ramen but my favorite is the tonkatsu ramen with pork belly, mild with garlic. The egg that's included in every bowl is delicious too!! The pork is a bit sweet and just melts in your mouth! The portions are just the right size to finish the bowl too. For appetizers, we've had the pan fried potstickers, chicken wings, fried cheese, and chicken karaage. All were yummy! When we go to Coco's we go all out because we know we're in for a good treat. Just writing this review makes me want to go back today!
author: Nicole B.

description: There isn't much great ramen in SF, so I was so delighted to discover that CoCo serves some straight up good ramen!  The tonkatsu broth with black garlic oil is umami and well balanced.  And to top it off, the runny egg is perfection!  I'll definitely be back.
author: Melissa L.

description:
I crave ramen on a consistent basis, and this is my current go-to. The place is in a sketchy area, but who cares. The interior is small and warm, and the service is good. But what you really want to know is: how is the ramen? BOMB! 

I get my standard miso and the broth is super flavorful, the noodles have a slight bite to them, and it's loaded with fresh veggies. You can adjust the spice to your liking as well. 

They also have really, really good seaweed salad. That stuff is addictive. My mouth is watering.

Bottom line: I will return and I highly recommend!
author: Jade F.

description:
4 stars for being a decent-good ramen place in the Bernal Heights/Outer Mission area. It's a nice addition to this neighborhood.

Minus one star for being 20%-25% too expensive with a starting price of $11.50 a bowl, plus charging for extras such as corn,egg,etc.  At that price point I expect top notch Japanese style ramen with excellent broth, great noodles, and quality condiments.

It's clear the owners are Chinese and the taste/flavors dont quite taste authentic or good enough to justify the $11.50 starting price...

They either need to improve the quality of their broth and condiments or reduce their prices by $2-$2.50 per bowl..
author: Zk K.

description: Best ramen. Soft boiled eggs, tons of pork belly, black garlic and fresh veggies. Cheap and generous portions.
author: Ashley K.

description: Amazing simple quick high quality ramen. Come here at least once a month. Tonkotsu is super rich and great. Shoyu is great too. And the home made Cocos gyoza is the best I've had in SF. Get it.
author: Brooks D.

description: This was the first place I ever tasted Ramen and it's SO good! It's very small and usually has a bit of a wait on the weekends but definitely worth going to, their Ramen is amazing!!!
author: Tatum S.

description:
We were one of two groups in Coco's Ramen today at 2:27 or so when Nizaria D came in and pulled a weird Yelp stunt. 

Attention Nizaria D --  they had called last call to everyone in there about 10 minutes or more before you came in. (Coco's Ramen closes for lunch at 2:30.) -- 

Then, you came in. You were told you they weren't serving lunch any more. You left, wrote a scathing Yelp one star review, came back in, showed it to them on your phone, and stormed off!

Yikes.

What, they're supposed to seat you at 2:29 so you can be there until 3:15? Most restaurants don't function that way for lunch. You should know that before you put a restaurant whose food you obviously like on blast. 

Anyway, as to my review, the food here was good, a pleasant surprise. I got the Shoya mildly spicy with pork belly. My wife got the Tonkatsu with pork loin. We also got agedashi tofu, eggplant, and the grilled squid. All quite tasty. Nice, professional service.
author: kenny k.

description: Great new ramen spot in Bernal!  The Kabocha appetizer was phenomenal with perfectly cooked egg surrounded by a sweet , mashed pumpkin blanket. I also tried the Tonkotsu ramen with garlic, a soft boiled egg, and extra pork belly (drooooling as I write this)! Everything was wonderful and rich in taste, service, and atmosphere!! Good stuff!
author: Kaitlyn D.

description: This place will always hold a special place in my heart because they serve quality ramen on Mondays. I always want ramen on monday and all the other good places near me are closed. I'd say the ramen is a solid 8/10, and they give a bunch of options such as black garlic and spiciness level. I love it. I am giving them 5 stars, even though I think it's a 4 star place I'm adding one for their schedule.
author: Geoff G.

description: It is a decent ramen spot to get your fixin' if you live by the area or are around the area. The spicy tonkatsu with pork belly and black garlic oil (additional $1) is pretty good (3/5) but not very consistent. The bf's always gets miso ramen and it not never rich like stated on the menu and is pretty bland. Overall, I have only come back if I don't feel like driving deep into the city to get some ramen.
author: Rachel N.

description:
This place opened just in time for winter and I couldn't be happier about it. 

I had the Miso broth, with Garlic, medium spicy, with kimchi. The noodles were perfectly chewy and the broth was wonderfully salty & had great depth with the garlic & spice.

The decor is almost mockingly old-school, which brought some formality to the friendly service. The music was a little off, I am not sure why but it stood out too much instead of being in the background.

Great addition to the neighborhood and I look forward to exploring the menu further.
author: Ge O.

description:
3 stars for offering take-out service where no other ramen place in the area seems to.

Taste-wise the Tonkatsu ramen seemed blander than what I remember from other places, but the pork belly was delicious.
author: Gleb P.

description: Coco's is definitely one of my favorite ramen spots in the city. Delicious broth, delicious noodles, everything is great.
author: Gil M.

description:
Excellent kabocha (pumpkin ball), ramen, grilled whole squid and chicken wings.

Pleasant service.

They need to rethink the table / chair layout on the ramen side of the restaurant. All five tables were taken up yet six chairs remained empty. And some tables that were up against the benches wasted seating space. They could have easily accommodated six more people in one hour.

TO THE BUSINESS OWNER:

Get smaller, two-person tables so you don't waste 2 chairs when it's only two people dining at a 4-person table. Rearrange these smaller tables into larger tables as needed. Rethink how to put these smaller tables against your bench seating to maximize use of the space. The large, heavy wooden tables you have now may look nice but you're losing business. You can get smaller, modern looking tables and still keep the ambiance since your decor is pretty modern anyway. Don't worry about putting the tables closer together. If you look at other restaurants, the tables are closer (but not too close). Your food is really good; people come to your place for the food, not the romantic ambiance.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I was excited to have ramen in the neighborhood, but I was sorely disappointed this afternoon. I'm very sensitive to spicy foods, so I made sure to order the "mild" version of the Tonkotsu ramen. When it arrived, it was so orange-colored from chili oil and shichimi that I double-checked with the server that it was indeed the mild. I was able to eat some of the noodles, but the broth was so spicy that I could not eat it. 
I've lived in Japan, and ramen isn't spicy there unless it's specifically requested. Perhaps Coco's thinks all Americans love spicy foods, or they think it's a good way to disguise a relatively flavorless tonkotsu-style broth. When I mentioned that I couldn't eat it, they gave me some lame advice about asking for the spicy paste (which isn't mentioned on the menu at all) on the side next time. I don't think there will be a next time.

The chicken gyoza were pan-fried nicely, but inside they were mushy and not very good.

$20 gone and I'm still hungry. Buyer beware.
author: kelly r.

description:
Umami in a bowl!

My friend and I went here after starting the day with some soothing yoga. Upon arrival, we were immediately given a table. It was already 1:30 pm and my appetite was voracious. There were only about 10 spots available and at that time only one server. We were lucky to get in when we did as the place soon filled up. I ordered the shio signature ramen (for a refreshing broth) with chasu and boy did it satisfy. Not only was the presentation of the ramen nice, flavors were perfectly balanced, representing the epitome of umami awesomeness! Service was slow but since the server was so kind and the ramen so divine, it was worth it. Prices start at about $11.50 a bowl. I'll be back!
author: Judy P.

description:
Very good veggie ramen; Reminds me of Japan! Great selection of other types as well. I'm excited to try their fried pumpkin with the egg in the center.

I'm sure they're still working things out here. But it was a good experience for the first day!
author: Tim R.

description:
Compared to all the ramen places in Japantown and Richmond area, this is a ok place. Don't get me wrong, it is good to have a neighborhood ramen place, just the ramen soup isn't as thick and creamy as those I've have elsewhere, even the creamier ones this place recommended to me. 

I would continue go to this place for convenience purposes, if I do have time, I would go to Japantown.
author: Shijia L.

description: We were expecting a little better based on the average of reviews around 4/5. They were friendly folks, and the sake selection is good, but the food is pretty average. The edamame were overcooked, we had two orders of gyoza and the second one was much less cooked than the first, the squid was not as fresh as we would have expected, and the ramen was not so flavorful. Just average.
author: Doug B.

description:
I'll preface this by saying that I'm normally pretty picky about where I eat my ramen and even though I read some reviews that made me unsure if I should try this place, I was pretty excited about the prospect of having decent ramen close to my house.

The staff is very polite and the restaurant is very clean. No complaints there. I'm giving this place 2/5 stars because the tonkotsu ramen is one of the worst that I have -ever- had.  If you're looking for other food or a non tonkotsu ramen perhaps the rating would be higher. My friend and I adventure around the Bay Area trying all the tonkotsu ramens from Ramen Dojo, Himawari, Ramen Parlor, Orenchi, ramen underground, Ken Ken among many many others. 

This tonkotsu was overpriced and very strange. It was almost a chinese take on ramen? My friend hit the nail on the head when we were trying to figure out what was weird about the pork belly-the pork belly had a christmas-y spice to it that was very unappealing. The noodles were okay, nothing to rave about but the broth was very unsatisfying an the broth is why my fat self loves tonkotsu. I'm a fan of spicy but unfortunately when you ask for spicy here they add a spice which mutates the "should be delicate" tonkotsu broth. It loses the creamy pork allure.

Again, nice people and clean but I don't recommend going for tonkotsu.

Ps. If you charge that much for ramen you should at least include a WHOLE egg instead of a half.
author: Katie A.

description: Delicious vegetarian ramen! Medium spicy was perfect for me and I like that you can choose your veggies. I'll be back!
author: Shal J.

description:
Came here for dinner at 830pm on a Monday night with my husband. 

Pros: I had the tonkatsu with pork belly (added black garlic and an extra slow-cooked egg). Very flavorful broth and pork-belly, loved the egg. The husband got the seafood ramen which was also yummy. Nice ambience once you got inside. 

Cons: Wait time was 25 minutes and service was pretty bad - really slow going to bring us water and forgetful about things we asked for like napkins or an extra plate (we gave up after a while). They also aren't straightforward about the wait time when you put your name down. 

Suggestions to Cocos: you could significantly reduce customer wait times if you put in two tops instead of 4 tops (especially since you seat 2 people at a 4 person table). And you're painfully understaffed. 

Bottom line: there are way better ramen spots in the City, but this one's within walking distance of my house. We'd do takeout but not likely we'll do a sit down dinner here again.
author: Sarah F.

description: Mediocre ramen, I got Tonkotsu with black garlic and my girlfriend got normal Tonkotsu. Hers literally tasted like the Shin Bowl pre-packaged ramen with added meats and egg. For the price you pay and comparing this to other ramen shops, I'd rate this place 2.5-3 stars. It also took a little over 30 minutes to get our food.
author: Chris N.

description: KEEP YOUR RECEIPT!!! They overcharged credit card by 200% i do not appreciate having to spend my time off calling in the clear up this error. The Ramen was okay but not worth going back and risking this happening again. If my friend insists on going back here I am paying cash. Then again if I can't trust them to charge the correct amount that is stated in front of them how can i expect them to handle my food!
author: Reema I.

description:
Best ramen this side of the sunset, New lunch place found! 

The menu keeps things simple and easy but just about everything on it is pretty great. 

Each ramen bowl is tailored to a certain taste, rich, creamy, salty etc. and everyone is completely different and fantastic in its own way, so it really just depends on what you like. 

The service is quick helpful and polite, and the prices are pretty standard for the area.
author: Joe N.

description: Something about the ramen there was not appealing. It has a pungent odor and a lingering taste which did not leave our pallets satisfied
author: Milana R.

description:
So filling, several selections.  My boyfriend and I got the Tonkatsu and the Shoyu.  I think I liked the Shoyu better but both were good.  Ordered them mild and they still had a touch of heat to them which we liked.  We got the chasu which is leaner pork than the pork belly they also offer.  It was nice and flavorful.  The noodles are so satisfying.  

Prices also seemed reasonable at about 11-12/bowl.  Waited for about 40 minutes for a table for four at 9pm on a Friday.
author: Katie C.

description: This place ranks on the Thrillist Best Ramen in SF, and it is clear why. The bowls are excellent, particularly if you like your ramen hot spicy as I do, with a wide range of classic ramen broths and fresh ingredients. That said, while they indicate a range of hot spicing preference options, and the waiter actively engaged in conversation regarding the topic, we were surprised when my partner's bowl was delivered medium spicy though she had very clearly stated "no spice". When they suggested a completely different type of ramen, salty shio, and then brought that, they again offered hot pepper spice. The point here seems to be one of communications. So, if you need your dish without absolutely no hot spice, be really, really clear on that, ask for recommendation of a bland or salty broth, and reiterate your preference. They seem to be attentive to pleasing the customer, even if it takes some perseverance on both sides, and the extra communication effort is worthwhile.
author: Scott C.

description: Favorite ramen in SF.  The curry ramen with pork belly, black garlic, kimchi extra spicy is amazing.  The fried pumpkin egg app is worth ordering too!
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Not a bad bowl of soup, although it was VERY salty. The worst service I've ever experienced. A few of the highlights include: 

1) Being crossed off of the wait list three times while we were waiting outside. They said they called our name, but never did. Then they started seating parties that came much later than us. Why? Who knows. 

2) Being sat in the sushi restaurant (attached to the ramen restaurant) and having the server be mean to us as though it was our fault that we were sat there. 

3) Waiting 40 plus minutes for ramen and being told that it was because they had to serve all of the customers in the other restaurant first (even if they came 40 minutes after us, huh?!?!). 

4) The waiter got our order wrong after all of that and said that we ordered wrong. 

5) They said that they would comp one bowl of ramen after we complained of the bad experience and then brought us a bill for $37.  Two minutes later they said it was the wrong bill and then brought us one for $50. Hah, pure comedy at this point. 

Bottom line: I will never go here again and strongly advise against it.
author: Josh S.

description: Great ramen spot in Bernal Heights. Really cozy rustic looking interior and all the staff members are really nice. I ordered the to tonkatsu ramen ($11.50) and everything from the broth to the meat were made well. Good alternative to those days when you're not feeling like pho and want something more flavorful.
author: Angela K.

description: As expected, this is a small restaurant with a lot of love for food and their customers.  We were fortunately able to arrive before the wave of evening patrons and without a reservation, we sat outside, enjoyed the great weather and quick service.  They don't serve hard liquor but offered a healthy selection of wine, beer and sake.  I ordered the Miso Ramen with black garlic and tofu (really flavorful, hearty, creamy and reminded me of a great soup on a fall day).  My dinner mate ordered the Shio Ramen with chicken and had leftovers for the next day.  I would certainly come here again, next time I'll have the Seafood Ramen, I've been told it is really delightful and refreshing.
author: Brett D.

description: Misled by all the great ratings that this is a good ramen place.   Star Anise and clove taste lingers in the broth and pork, nothing umami about that and nothing authenticate about this place.  Will not come back.
author: Vien C.

description: Miso ramen was quite good. Avoid getting the yellowtail hamachi. It's not worth the price for a bite of fried salt. Ambience is laid back and the wood decor is relaxing. Service is quick and great!
author: Tiffany J.

description: This place is at the top of my list for Ramen in the Bay. If you want a super rich broth, perfectly cooked egg and noodles, this is your spot. Add the black garlic for more depth of flavor. I have yet to be disappointed here.
author: Allan A.

description: Best ramen in SF to me. Miso spicy with the pork belly and extra slow cooked egg smacks every time. Wish the place was bigger but it is clean, nice, with good service and solid prices. Only thing bad is their gyoza is only average.
author: Michael Z.

description:
simple good tasting ramen.

its not too far from the freeway and doesnt have crazy lines. it actually makes for a convenient to-go ramen place if you find a parking spot.
author: Alex H.

description: Yummy!!! My favorite ramen place in greater mission!! I had the miso with pork belly! Me gustas mucho!
author: Xiu L.

description: Good food, good service, but a big issue for me - the seating concerns they have piss me off. The staff asked people to move from the seats they were at so a party of more could sit. A guy was asked to move from the window seat to the bar because a couple came in: the window seat has two chairs. That's wrong. All customers should be treated fairly. If you get to the restaurant before others, then you get 1st pick. It's not as though the guy at the window is less important than 2 customers who came in 150mins after he. I'm wavering on coming back here. Treating customers like this is wring.
author: Erik T.

description: We visited this past Sunday night. Everything tasted super good! I had the miso base ramen with black garlic and pork shoulder, medium spicy. It was soo flavorful. We had the poke appetizer, which also tasted great and very fresh. My only complaint was that the ramen came out of the kitchen before the poke, which was odd, and there were no chips or anything served with the poke the help us eat it (turns out mango is pretty difficult to pick up with chopsticks). We'll definitely be coming back though - it was a very tasty dinner and a lot of food for a decent price.
author: Medina C.

description:
Good food, horrible service. All our orders were wrong, with one person getting their food well after everyone else had finished eating. We had to constantly remind them what our order was as they kept bringing out wrong ramen. We didn't have especially complicated orders either: tonkotsu with chashu, extra spicy, extra egg. 

No apologies from the staff and they automatically added 20% gratuity for our party of 6. I usually am not a fan of reviews where restaurants are docked points for service, but in this case it was horrific. It went beyond just rude service into terrible service. The food was good, so the chefs did a great job, but the servers ruined our experience.
author: Nina H.

description: Yummo.  I have a stupid cold and have lost my stupid voice.  I long for the healing power of almighty ramen.  Coco's did not let a girl down! Found parking right in front (miracle) and it was ready in about thirty.  Could've been spicier but for me, everything could ALWAYS be spicier. Spicy miso ramen, heal me!
author: julie a.

description: Awesome ramen here! Show up early, there's not a lot of room and usually long lines.
author: David F.

description: Not a super Ramen fan, but this place made me change my mind with one bowl of Tonkotsu. The broth was fantastic! The pork belly was succulent and savory, with enough to last the entire meal. Plus, it came with an egg and delicious, tender Ramen noodles. It was cozy, not loud, and a great place for a hot cup of food love on a cold Sunday night.
author: Jake A.

description: Omg adore this place, this is my go-to ramen spot. The atmosphere is so nice, upper mission's best secret for ramen. Get the cold house sake, it's refreshing and served in such a cute and unique carafe. I Love all the styles of ramen here. I also love that you can get a variety of Japanese dishes, I always get shishito peppers with my meal, sometimes fresh oysters. Great for some solo ramen time, gets super busy for a good reason. Expect a wait during peak times if you go with company.
author: Chiquita S.

description: The ramen was okay but really just passable. The service was not friendly. The bathroom was not equipped. I'm not going back and wouldn't recommend it in this state.
author: Maryam M.

description: This place has some decent ramen. It's cooked al dente so the noodles have a nice textural bite. The shoyu ramen left me drinking the entire bottle of water so maybe next time I'd opt for something with less sodium. All in all, this is a nice addition to the neighborhood and I wish it the best. Maybe I'll come back for the Crazy Sushi next time. J-town is still my go to spot for a nice steaming bowl of ramen though.
author: W A.

description:
Not sure what I expected here but it was ok. There was a sort of packaged taste to the broth,  but hey,  even packaged ramen is ok. 

Overall I'd say the ramen here is on par with the sushi on the other side of the space Crazy Sushi. Not great but you won't get sick or anything. 

Price is affordable,  service is friendly.
author: Victoria W.

description: I loved the pork belly in the ramen, it was excellent. Good sake selection and great service.
author: B F.

description: This place is surprisingly good. We ordered pork belly skewer, yellow tail, eggplant, grilled squid, one tonkatsu ramen and one miso ramen. Pork belly was really tasty, second were two ramen bowls, yellow tail was good, squid tasted kinda bland and just forget about the eggplant. Overall, good experience and glad to have a descent ramen place in the hood!
author: Yina M.

description: first time here.  ordered the Miso Ramen, broth is kinda watery not creamy and not very authentic miso flavor. Lacking the garlic miso flavor.  The staff all speak Chinese, maybe they have Chinese cook , cooking Japanese food. Kinda odd. No wonder it tasted watery.  I guess I'm not recommending this place to anyone for Ramen and not coming back.
author: Raymund D.

description: Pretty awesome ramen! The Japanese eggplant is very good too! Definitely come back.
author: Snowdrops C.

description: Came here as a party of two and were served delicious Japanese ramen. I ordered pork belly ramen with egg. Pork belly is juicy but not fatty. It goes well with the black garlic soup. The half-cooked egg was AMAZING. I could have three or four of these eggs. Dreaammm.... Will definitely come back to try the other flavors.
author: Jess F.

description: Not bad, slow service and the place is a little dirty.  Otherwise decent place that I would consider going back to.
author: Joe P.

description:
The best veggie ramen in SF!! I've had my share of vegetarian ramens in San Francisco (especially because when I first moved here, I made it my mission to find a ramen place I could frequent), and this is the best I've found! There are a lot of options for what to add to the ramen, and the broth is so delicious! The egg is perfectly cooked; there's nothing bad about this bowl of ramen. 

The downside, however, is that service is really bad. One thing I don't really understand is why they don't let people sit in the sushi restaurant to eat ramen...the sushi restaurant which is connected to the ramen restaurant has the same owners, and there is literally no one in there...ever. But there is a line for the ramen often 10-15 minutes long...why not just seat those customers in there? Additionally, the wait staff can be very rude sometimes, and if they aren't rude, they still take a really long time to take orders, bring the check, and clear the check. Everything just takes a long time. The ramen is so good though, that I will keep coming back (and maybe they know that...)!
author: Melanie W.

description: Really good ramen. Came in with a group of 3 on Sunday dinner, right before the 6:30 rush and were seated immediately. Service was pretty slow throughout, but food was top notch. I don't eat pork and was able to get the seafood ramen with the vegan broth; it was delicious. Medium spicy, which was pretty spicy (good).
author: Jelani G.

description: Good ramen. A little bit of a wait (30 minutes) most of the time. They tend to be a bit dismissive of patrons at times, especially when busy, but the food is good. I always get the tonkatsu with chashu and it never disappoints. The chashu is tender and flavorful, and the soft boiled egg is always perfect!
author: Lana H.

description: Delicious ramen! I ordered the Tonkatsu with pork belly. I can't wait to go back.
author: James P.

description:
A couple weeks ago I was Jonesing for some Ramen, but didn't want to make the Trek to the Richmond to get my fix. I had all but given up, and was going to hit the same old same old Pho or Thai places when I walked by this Ramen place.

With only one other patron there at 5:30pm ish, I figured I'd risk it and give it a chance. Since it was so new, the waitress unfortunately couldn't give my wife and I the most experienced recommendations of the appetizers so we took a chance on the Gyoza which we happily enjoyed.

For our main course I had the Tonkatsu, and my wife had the Seafood. I was extremely happy with the taste, and soon more and more patrons came it.

I liked the small size of the place, quality food, and the fact it isn't packed to the gills just yet. I will definitely make sure to keep coming back.
author: Dane M.

description:
Average Ramen - not bad, but definitely did not stand out. I live next to Iza Ramen (pop-up hosted by Blowfish sushi) and have it every few weekends, so in comparison this was nothing special.  
At Coco's, I had the Tonkotsu ramen, which should be a bit rich and creamy - this was neither.  It was thin, more akin to a shio broth than tonkotsu.  The pork was a bit dry, and the egg - though soft cooked - was pretty small.    Given the price, I'd look elsewhere, as there are many good choices in SF (though not necessarily in the vicinity of this restaurant.
author: Seth G.

description:
Don't know if they have a new cook but I had to send the first order (classic shoyu) back and the left after I sent the second back and it was still tasteless, oily and disgusting. 

I'd been here at least 5 times and while I never thought it was great, it was okay and satisfied the ramen craving. 

I'll give it one more shot but it's now on the do not return watch list
author: Dan E.

description: go for the ramen, stay for the sushi, sake, and homemade gyoza. love u coco.
author: Yves D.

description: Great ramen, the Tonkotsu with pork belly is my go to. Can get crowded for dinner as it is a pretty small space, but usually you can find a seat easily for lunch. Also decent to go.
author: Kyle F.

description: Had lunch there with four people. We all ordered ramen (tonkatsu, seafood, and vegetarian) and it was great all around. Great service and attentive.
author: Dan S.

description: Delicious Ramen!  I tried the Takotsu (creamy) & added pork belly & black garlic.  I will be back for more!
author: Jon S.

description: Tried this place out this past weekend with my family, we all got the Tonkastu ramen with either chashu or pork belly and mild spiciness. I got the chashu cause I was hesitant about the amount of fat surround the pork belly from the photos, but after trying my sister's pork belly I was pleasantly surprised with how delicious it was. They marinate the meat prior to serving it, so it's really flavorful with a tinge of sweetness, I definitely liked it more than the chashu. The "medium" spiciness wasn't spicy at all actually so I wish I had ordered "hot" instead. The broth here is also delicious, not water downed or plain like other ramen shops I went to, and the egg is also cooked just right with a soft yolk center. I will definitely come back when I'm in town and try their other ramens.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I LOVE Coco's Ramen. Ever since I started going I have cravings, so luckily I live around the corner. Happy me.
author: Yvette K.

description: Miso ramen and tonkotsu were extremely salty. One of the waiters was cold and rude. Price was adequate, but I don't think I'd return.
author: Tango N.

description: I've been here a couple of times now and I've enjoyed their veggie ramen each time!  My bowl comes with ample ramen and makes me full every time. I also love how there's never really a long wait :-). Fellow tellers, please don't overcrowd this place!
author: Christina C.

description: Delicious tonkotsu ramen!! Small neighborhood joint so sometimes a wait. Noodles perfectly al dente and rich, delicious broth.
author: B. Y.

description: The Ramen is very good, but pretty overpriced. After all is said and done, expect to pay at least $15 for your soup. The photos look amazing but unfortunately is not realistic. Maybe some people got lucky, but I've been to this place several times and I never get more than one tiny strip of meat in my soup. So don't trust the photos that look like they are filled with meat.  Service is not terrible but mediocre. Also if you are a vegetarian or don't like meat, they don't do substitutions. My roommate doesn't like her ramen with meat, and tried to just get extra broth instead of meat, they charged her for it anyway and made a really heavy point about it. The place is also small and crowded, expect to wait for a table (although the wait is never more than 15 minutes), but not really a good place for a date or for a group. Just an overpriced soup joint
author: Quest H.

description: Always on the quest for good ramen, my friend and I dined here last Friday for dinner. We arrived at 7:30pm, surprisingly there was no wait for a table. For starters. we ordered the bacon wrapped mochi and chicken karaage, both were not very memorable. I ordered the Tonkastu Ramen with the braised pork belly. I felt the braised pork belly was tender but it unexpectedly had a five spice flavor to it (the spice is commonly used in Chinese and Vietnamese cooking). The broth reminded me of Ajisen. There are definitely more authentic Japanese ramen places in the area aka not Chinese owned. If your favorite ramen places are Orenchi and Dojo, I'd skip Coco's because you'll leave craving ramen from one of those two places and will feel the ridiculous wait times at those establishments would of been worth your time.
author: Nettie K.

description: Yum, yum. Very good Ramen. I had the Tonkotsu Ramen with Black Garlic -- delicious! Great atmosphere and staff. So happy they opened in this part of Mission. This is going to become a regular spot for me :)
author: Zelda F.

description:
